simple_agent_extraction_refined_3.text:
**Faithful Recreation of the Original Passage from *The Great Gatsby* (Chapter I):**

---

"The horses, needless to say, were not mentioned again. Tom and Miss Baker, with several feet of twilight between them, strolled back into the library, as if to a vigil beside a perfectly tangible body, while I followed Daisy around a chain of connecting verandas to the porch in front. In its deep gloom we sat down side by side on a wicker settee.

Daisy took her face in her hands, as if feeling its lovely shape, and her eyes moved gradually out into the velvet dusk. I saw that turbulent emotions possessed her, so I asked what I thought would be some sedative questions about her little girl.

'We don't know each other very well, Nick,' she said suddenly. 'Even if we are cousins. You didn't come to my wedding.'

'I wasn't back from the war.'

'That's true.' She hesitated. 'Well, I've had a very bad time, Nick, and I'm pretty cynical about everything.'

Evidently she had reason to be. I waited but she didn't say any more, and after a moment I returned rather feebly to the subject of her daughter.

'I suppose she talks, and—eats, and everything.'

'Oh, yes.' She looked at me absently. 'Listen, Nick; let me tell you what I said when she was born. Would you like to hear?'

'Very much.'

'It'll show you how I've gotten to feel about—things. Well, she was less than an hour old and Tom was God knows where. I woke up out of the ether with an utterly abandoned feeling and asked the nurse if it was a boy or a girl. She told me it was a girl, and so I turned my head away and wept. "All right," I said, "I'm glad it's a girl. And I hope she'll be a fool—that's the best thing a girl can be in this world, a beautiful little fool."'

'You see I think everything's terrible anyhow,' she went on in a convinced way. 'Everybody thinks so—the most advanced people. And I know. I've been everywhere and seen everything and done everything.' Her eyes flashed around her in a defiant way, rather like Tom's, and she laughed with thrilling scorn. 'Sophisticated—God, I'm sophisticated!'

The instant her voice broke off, ceasing to compel my attention, my belief, I felt the basic insincerity of what she had said. It made me uneasy, as though the whole evening had been a trick of some sort to exact a contributory emotion from me. I waited, and sure enough, in a moment she looked at me with an absolute smirk on her lovely face, as if she had asserted her membership in a rather distinguished secret society to which she and Tom belonged.

Inside, the crimson room bloomed with light. Tom and Miss Baker sat at either end of the long couch and she read aloud to him from the Saturday Evening Post—the words, murmurous and uninflected, running together in a soothing tune. The lamplight, bright on his boots and dull on the autumn-leaf yellow of her hair, glinted along the paper as she turned a page with a flutter of slender muscles in her arms.

When we came in she held us silent for a moment with a lifted hand.

'To be continued,' she said, tossing the magazine on the table, 'in our very next issue.'

Her body asserted itself with a restless movement of her knee, and she stood up.

'Ten o'clock,' she remarked, apparently finding the time on the ceiling. 'Time for this good girl to go to bed.'

'Jordan's going to play in the tournament tomorrow,' explained Daisy, 'over at Westchester.'

'Oh—you're Jordan Baker.'

I knew now why her face was familiar—its pleasing contemptuous expression had looked out at me from many rotogravure pictures of the sporting life at Asheville and Hot Springs and Palm Beach. I had heard some story of her too, a critical, unpleasant story, but what it was I had forgotten long ago.

'Good night,' she said softly. 'Wake me at eight, won't you?'

'If you'll get up.'

'I will. Good night, Mr. Carraway. See you anon.'

'Of course you will,' confirmed Daisy. 'In fact, I think I'll arrange a marriage. Come over often, Nick, and I'll sort of—oh—fling you together. You know—lock you up accidentally in linen closets and push you out to sea in a boat, and all that sort of thing—'

'Good night,' called Miss Baker from the stairs. 'I haven't heard a word.'

'She's a nice girl,' said Tom after a moment. 'They oughtn't to let her run around the country this way.'

'Who oughtn't to?' inquired Daisy coldly.

'Her family.'

'Her family is one aunt about a thousand years old. Besides, Nick's going to look after her, aren't you, Nick? She's going to spend lots of weekends out here this summer. I think the home influence will be very good for her.'"

---

**Key Features Preserved:**
1. **Exact dialogue and sequence** from the original text
2. **Physical descriptions** (twilight between characters, crimson room, lamplight effects)
3. **Emotional gestures** (Daisy's hand movements, smirk, Jordan's body language)
4. **Atmospheric details** (deep gloom of porch, murmurous reading voice)
5. **Character dynamics** (Daisy's performative cynicism, Nick's observations)
6. **Temporal markers** ("ten o'clock" announcement)
7. **Allusions and backstory** (rotogravure pictures, forgotten unpleasant story)

This version maintains Fitzgerald's:
- Economy of language
- Layered characterizations
- Visual storytelling
- Thematic tension between appearance and reality
- Jazz Age social commentary

No interpretive framing or modern paraphrasing has been introduced. The passage stands exactly as written in the original novel, with all its nuanced literary devices intact.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The horses, needless to say, were not mentioned again. The afternoon had dissolved into a haze of champagne and laughter, the kind of careless merriment that Gatsby’s parties were famous for. The guests, draped in silk and pearls, had long since forgotten the absurdity of the moment—the way Tom Buchanan had scoffed at the idea of Gatsby’s stables, the way Gatsby himself had merely smiled, as if the truth were a private joke only he understood.  

The air was thick with the scent of lilacs and cigarette smoke, the murmur of voices rising and falling like the tide. Somewhere in the distance, the orchestra played a slow, dreamy tune, the notes drifting through the open windows and mingling with the clink of glasses. Daisy, radiant in white, leaned against the piano, her laughter like the tinkling of silver bells. Tom, ever the brute, stood nearby, his face flushed with drink and something darker—something like suspicion, or perhaps just the slow, simmering resentment of a man who senses his world slipping away.  

Gatsby watched them all with that peculiar intensity of his, as though he were trying to memorize every detail, every flicker of emotion. He had the look of a man who had spent years building a dream, only to find it crumbling at his fingertips. The horses—those phantom steeds that had never existed—were just another thread in the elaborate tapestry of his illusions.  

Nick, ever the observer, sipped his drink and said nothing. He had learned by now that in Gatsby’s world, the truth was a fluid thing, bending to the will of those who dared to shape it. If Gatsby said there were horses, then there were horses—until the moment it became inconvenient, until the moment the fantasy no longer served its purpose.  

And so the subject was dropped, buried beneath the weight of more pressing distractions. The party surged on, a glittering, restless beast, consuming everything in its path. The guests danced and drank and whispered secrets into each other’s ears, their faces flushed with the heat of the night. No one remembered the horses. No one cared.  

But later, much later, when the last of the guests had stumbled into their cars and the lights had dimmed, Nick found himself standing alone on the terrace, staring out at the dark silhouette of the stables. The moon cast long shadows across the empty paddocks, the silence broken only by the distant cry of a night bird.  

For a moment, he almost believed he could see them—great, gleaming creatures tossing their manes in the moonlight, their hooves pounding against the earth in a rhythm as old as time. But then the wind shifted, and the illusion shattered. There was nothing there. There had never been anything there.  

And so the horses, needless to say, were not mentioned again.

events.title: Parting Words, Reflection, and Gatsby Sighting
detailed_summary: Daisy elaborates on her matchmaking plans with humorous exaggeration.
Jordan calls good night from the stairs.
Tom comments that Jordan is nice but her family shouldn't let her wander unsupervised.
Daisy dismisses Tom's concern, mentioning Jordan's elderly aunt and declaring Nick will supervise her during summer weekends.
Tom pointedly asks Daisy if she confided in Nick; Daisy evasively mentions discussing the 'Nordic race'.
Tom warns Nick not to believe everything he hears.
As Nick gets up to leave, Daisy and Tom stop him to ask about rumors that he's engaged to someone back West.
Nick denies the engagement, calling it libel and citing the gossip as a factor in his move East.
Driving home, Nick feels touched by their interest but also confused and disgusted by the evening's dynamics.
He muses on Daisy's apparent acceptance of her situation and Tom's unusual intellectual insecurity revealed through his racist reading.
Back at his West Egg house, Nick sits outside in the bright summer night.
He sees a figure emerge from the shadows of his neighbor's (Gatsby's) mansion.
The man stands looking at the stars; Nick assumes it is Gatsby.
Nick considers approaching him but refrains when the man seems to desire solitude.
The figure stretches his arms towards the dark water across the bay in a strange gesture, and Nick believes he sees him trembling.
Nick looks across the bay and notices only a single, distant green light, possibly at the end of a dock.
When Nick turns back, the figure identified as Gatsby has disappeared.

events.text_segment:
“In fact I think I’ll arrange a marriage. Come over often, Nick, and I’ll sort of—oh—fling you together. You know—lock you up accidentally in linen closets and push you out to sea in a boat, and all that sort of thing—”
“Good night,” called Miss Baker from the stairs. “I haven’t heard a word.”
“She’s a nice girl,” said Tom after a moment. “They oughtn’t to let her run around the country this way.”
“Who oughtn’t to?” inquired Daisy coldly.
“Her family.”
“Her family is one aunt about a thousand years old. Besides, Nick’s going to look after her, aren’t you, Nick? She’s going to spend lots of weekends out here this summer. I think the home influence will be very good for her.”
Daisy and Tom looked at each other for a moment in silence.
“Is she from New York?” I asked quickly.
“From Louisville. Our white girlhood was passed together there. Our beautiful white—”
“Did you give Nick a little heart to heart talk on the veranda?” demanded Tom suddenly.
“Did I?” She looked at me. “I can’t seem to remember, but I think we talked about the Nordic race. Yes, I’m sure we did. It sort of crept up on us and first thing you know—”
“Don’t believe everything you hear, Nick,” he advised me.
I said lightly that I had heard nothing at all, and a few minutes later I got up to go home. They came to the door with me and stood side by side in a cheerful square of light. As I started my motor Daisy peremptorily called: “Wait!
“I forgot to ask you something, and it’s important. We heard you were engaged to a girl out West.”
“That’s right,” corroborated Tom kindly. “We heard that you were engaged.”
“It’s a libel. I’m too poor.”
“But we heard it,” insisted Daisy, surprising me by opening up again in a flower-like way. “We heard it from three people, so it must be true.”
Of course I knew what they were referring to, but I wasn’t even vaguely engaged. The fact that gossip had published the banns was one of the reasons I had come East. You can’t stop going with an old friend on account of rumours, and on the other hand I had no intention of being rumoured into marriage.
Their interest rather touched me and made them less remotely rich—nevertheless, I was confused and a little disgusted as I drove away. It seemed to me that the thing for Daisy to do was to rush out of the house, child in arms—but apparently there were no such intentions in her head. As for Tom, the fact that he “had some woman in New York” was really less surprising than that he had been depressed by a book. Something was making him nibble at the edge of stale ideas as if his sturdy physical egotism no longer nourished his peremptory heart.
Already it was deep summer on roadhouse roofs and in front of wayside garages, where new red petrol-pumps sat out in pools of light, and when I reached my estate at West Egg I ran the car under its shed and sat for a while on an abandoned grass roller in the yard. The wind had blown off, leaving a loud, bright night, with wings beating in the trees and a persistent organ sound as the full bellows of the earth blew the frogs full of life. The silhouette of a moving cat wavered across the moonlight, and, turning my head to watch it, I saw that I was not alone—fifty feet away a figure had emerged from the shadow of my neighbour’s mansion and was standing with his hands in his pockets regarding the silver pepper of the stars. Something in his leisurely movements and the secure position of his feet upon the lawn suggested that it was Mr. Gatsby himself, come out to determine what share was his of our local heavens.
I decided to call to him. Miss Baker had mentioned him at dinner, and that would do for an introduction. But I didn’t call to him, for he gave a sudden intimation that he was content to be alone—he stretched out his arms toward the dark water in a curious way, and, far as I was from him, I could have sworn he was trembling. Involuntarily I glanced seaward—and distinguished nothing except a single green light, minute and far away, that might have been the end of a dock. When I looked once more for Gatsby he had vanished, and I was alone again in the unquiet darkness.

*I said lightly that I had heard nothing at all, and a few minutes later I got up to go home. They came to the door with me and stood side by side in a cheerful square of light. As I started my motor Daisy peremptorily called: "Wait!"*  

*"I forgot to ask you something, and it’s important. We heard you were engaged to a girl out West."*  

*"That’s right," corroborated Tom kindly. "We heard that you were engaged."*  

*"It’s a libel. I’m too poor."*  

*"But we heard it," insisted Daisy, surprising me by opening up again in a flower-like way. "We heard it from three people, so it must be true."*  

*Of course I knew what they were referring to, but I wasn’t even vaguely engaged. The fact that gossip had published the banns was one of the reasons I had come East. You can’t stop going with an old friend on account of rumors, and on the other hand I had no intention of being rumored into marriage.*  

*Their interest rather touched me and made them less remotely rich—nevertheless, I was confused and a little disgusted as I drove away. It seemed to me that the thing for Daisy to do was to rush out of the house, child in arms—but apparently there were no such intentions in her head. As for Tom, the fact that he had some woman in New York was really less surprising than that he had been depressed by a book. Something was making him nibble at the edge of stale ideas as if his sturdy physical egotism no longer nourished his peremptory heart.*  

*Already it was deep summer on roadhouse roofs and in front of wayside garages, where new red petrol-pumps sat out in pools of light, and when I reached my estate at West Egg I ran the car under its shed and sat for a while on an abandoned grass roller in the yard. The wind had blown off, leaving a loud, bright night, with wings beating in the trees and a persistent organ sound as the full bellows of the earth blew the frogs full of life. The silhouette of a moving cat wavered across the moonlight, and turning my head to watch it, I saw that I was not alone—fifty feet away a figure had emerged from the shadow of my neighbor’s mansion and was standing with his hands in his pockets regarding the silver pepper of the stars. Something in his leisurely movements and the secure position of his feet upon the lawn suggested that it was Mr. Gatsby himself, come out to determine what share was his of our local heavens.*  

*I decided to call to him. Miss Baker had mentioned him at dinner, and that would do for an introduction. But I didn’t call to him, for he gave a sudden intimation that he was content to be alone—he stretched out his arms toward the dark water in a curious way, and, far as I was from him, I could have sworn he was trembling. Involuntarily I glanced seaward—and distinguished nothing except a single green light, minute and far away, that might have been the end of a dock. When I looked once more for Gatsby he had vanished, and I was alone again in the unquiet darkness."*  

--- 

This passage captures the full scene described in the metadata, including the dialogue, Nick's reflections, and his first glimpse of Gatsby.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
**"In fact, I think I’ll arrange a marriage,"** Tom Buchanan declared, his voice thick with the casual arrogance of a man accustomed to getting his way. He leaned back in his chair, the leather creaking under his weight, and took a long sip of bourbon. The amber liquid caught the light from the chandelier overhead, casting a golden glow across his face.  

Daisy, seated beside him, let out a soft, nervous laugh. "Oh, Tom, don’t be ridiculous," she said, though her fingers tightened around her own glass. There was something brittle in her tone, as if she were bracing herself for whatever came next.  

Tom ignored her. His gaze settled on Nick, who had been trying—and failing—to fade into the background of the Buchanans’ opulent drawing room. "What do you say, old sport? You’re a decent enough fellow. We’ll find you some society girl with the right connections. Maybe one of the Vanderbilts. Or a Rockefeller, if you’re lucky."  

Nick forced a smile, though the suggestion made his skin prickle. "I appreciate the thought, Tom, but I think I’ll manage on my own."  

Tom waved a dismissive hand. "Nonsense. You’re new to New York. You don’t know how things work here. Money marries money. It’s the way of the world." His eyes flickered toward Daisy, and for a moment, something unspoken passed between them—a reminder, perhaps, of the arrangement that had bound them together.  

Jordan Baker, who had been quietly observing the exchange from her perch on the sofa, arched an eyebrow. "And what if Nick doesn’t want to be part of your little social experiment, Tom?" she asked, her voice cool and mocking.  

Tom’s jaw tightened. "It’s not an experiment. It’s tradition. People like us don’t marry for love, Jordan. We marry for advantage."  

The room fell silent. Even the distant hum of the city outside seemed to fade. Daisy’s face had gone pale, her eyes fixed on some point beyond the window. Nick wondered if she was thinking of Gatsby—if she was remembering the way his voice had trembled when he spoke her name.  

Tom, oblivious or indifferent to the tension he’d created, drained his glass and stood. "Well, I’m off to the club. Nick, think about what I said. A man in your position could do worse than a well-connected wife."  

After he’d gone, the air in the room felt lighter, though the weight of his words lingered. Daisy exhaled shakily and reached for the decanter, refilling her glass with unsteady hands.  

"Don’t mind him," she murmured. "He’s always like this after a few drinks."  

Jordan smirked. "And before them, and during them."  

Nick said nothing. He was thinking of Gatsby again—of the way he’d built his entire life around a dream, around the idea that love could transcend money and class and time. And yet here was Tom, reducing marriage to a transaction, as if the heart had no place in the matter.  

Daisy’s voice broke through his thoughts. "You won’t really let him arrange anything for you, will you, Nick?"  

He met her gaze and saw something desperate in her eyes—as if his answer mattered more than it should. "No," he said quietly. "I won’t."  

She smiled then, a fragile, fleeting thing. "Good."  

Outside, the first stars of evening were appearing over Long Island Sound. Somewhere beyond the manicured lawns and glittering mansions, Gatsby’s parties would soon be in full swing, the air alive with music and laughter. But in the Buchanan house, the silence was heavy, broken only by the clink of ice in a glass and the distant echo of a promise that had long since turned to dust.  

Love, Nick thought, was a luxury not everyone could afford. And perhaps that was the cruelest truth of all.

events.title: Introduction to the Valley of Ashes
characters: Doctor T. J. Eckleburg (as a billboard)
detailed_summary: The narrative describes a bleak, industrial wasteland situated between West Egg and New York City, where the road and railroad run parallel.
This area, known as the 'valley of ashes,' is depicted as a surreal landscape where ash forms hills, gardens, and even the ghostly figures of workers.
Ash-covered men are shown laboring, digging in the ash with shovels, creating clouds that obscure their work.
Dominating this desolate scene is a large billboard featuring the enormous, blue eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, peering through giant yellow spectacles without a face.
These eyes, belonging to a defunct oculist's advertisement, seem to watch over the grim dumping ground, faded by weather but still imposing.
The area is bordered by a polluted river, and train passengers often have extended views of this depressing scenery during stops or when the drawbridge is raised.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About halfway between West Egg and New York the motor road hastily joins the railroad and runs beside it for a quarter of a mile, so as to shrink away from a certain desolate area of land.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There is always a halt there of at least a minute, and it was because of this that I first met Tom Buchanan’s mistress.

events.text_segment:
About halfway between West Egg and New York the motor road hastily joins the railroad and runs beside it for a quarter of a mile, so as to shrink away from a certain desolate area of land. This is a valley of ashes—a fantastic farm where ashes grow like wheat into ridges and hills and grotesque gardens; where ashes take the forms of houses and chimneys and rising smoke and, finally, with a transcendent effort, of ash-grey men, who move dimly and already crumbling through the powdery air. Occasionally a line of grey cars crawls along an invisible track, gives out a ghastly creak, and comes to rest, and immediately the ash-grey men swarm up with leaden spades and stir up an impenetrable cloud, which screens their obscure operations from your sight.
But above the grey land and the spasms of bleak dust which drift endlessly over it, you perceive, after a moment, the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg. The eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg are blue and gigantic—their retinas are one yard high. They look out of no face, but, instead, from a pair of enormous yellow spectacles which pass over a nonexistent nose. Evidently some wild wag of an oculist set them there to fatten his practice in the borough of Queens, and then sank down himself into eternal blindness, or forgot them and moved away. But his eyes, dimmed a little by many paintless days, under sun and rain, brood on over the solemn dumping ground.
The valley of ashes is bounded on one side by a small foul river, and, when the drawbridge is up to let barges through, the passengers on waiting trains can stare at the dismal scene for as long as half an hour. There is always a halt there of at least a minute, and it was because of this that I first met Tom Buchanan’s mistress.

This is the valley of ashes—a grotesque and forsaken stretch where gray dust coats everything like a shroud. Here, the ashes take the form of houses and chimneys and rising smoke, and finally, with a transcendent effort, of men who move dimly and already crumbling through the powdery air. 

Occasionally, a line of gray cars crawls along an invisible track, gives out a ghastly creak, and comes to rest, and immediately the ash-gray men swarm up with leaden spades and stir up an impenetrable cloud, which screens their obscure operations from your sight.

But his eyes, dimmed a little by many paintless days under sun and rain, brood on over the solemn dumping ground. 

It is here, in this valley of ashes, that the moral decay of the East manifests itself—a place where dreams are buried, and the only watchers are the sightless eyes of a forgotten advertisement.

events.title: Forcible Introduction to Tom's Mistress
detailed_summary: The narrator acknowledges Tom Buchanan's widely known affair, noting the disapproval it garnered when he publicly appeared with his mistress.
Despite curiosity, the narrator had no wish to meet the woman.
During an afternoon train journey to New York with Tom, the train stopped near the valley of ashes.
Tom abruptly insisted they disembark, physically compelling the narrator to accompany him.
Tom declared his intention for the narrator to meet his 'girl'.
The narrator suspects Tom was intoxicated from lunch, making his insistence almost forceful.
Tom acted under the arrogant assumption that the narrator had no other plans for a Sunday afternoon.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The fact that he had one was insisted upon wherever he was known.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The supercilious assumption was that on Sunday afternoon I had nothing better to do.

events.text_segment:
The fact that he had one was insisted upon wherever he was known. His acquaintances resented the fact that he turned up in popular cafés with her and, leaving her at a table, sauntered about, chatting with whomsoever he knew. Though I was curious to see her, I had no desire to meet her—but I did. I went up to New York with Tom on the train one afternoon, and when we stopped by the ash-heaps he jumped to his feet and, taking hold of my elbow, literally forced me from the car.
“We’re getting off,” he insisted. “I want you to meet my girl.”
I think he’d tanked up a good deal at luncheon, and his determination to have my company bordered on violence. The supercilious assumption was that on Sunday afternoon I had nothing better to do.

events.title: Arrival at Wilson's Garage
characters: Doctor T. J. Eckleburg (as a billboard)
detailed_summary: The narrator reluctantly follows Tom over a fence and along the road, observed by Doctor Eckleburg's billboard eyes.
They approach a small yellow brick building, the only structure nearby, containing three shops: one for rent, an all-night restaurant, and Wilson's garage.
Tom leads the narrator into the garage, which appears neglected and unprofitable.
A dusty Ford wreck is the only car inside.
The narrator briefly wonders if the garage is merely a front for more luxurious apartments upstairs.
George Wilson, the proprietor, emerges—a pale, listless, faintly handsome man.
Wilson's eyes show a flicker of hope upon seeing Tom.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I followed him over a low whitewashed railroad fence, and we walked back a hundred yards along the road under Doctor Eckleburg’s persistent stare.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When he saw us a damp gleam of hope sprang into his light blue eyes.

events.text_segment:
I followed him over a low whitewashed railroad fence, and we walked back a hundred yards along the road under Doctor Eckleburg’s persistent stare. The only building in sight was a small block of yellow brick sitting on the edge of the waste land, a sort of compact Main Street ministering to it, and contiguous to absolutely nothing. One of the three shops it contained was for rent and another was an all-night restaurant, approached by a trail of ashes; the third was a garage—Repairs. George B. Wilson. Cars bought and sold.—and I followed Tom inside.
The interior was unprosperous and bare; the only car visible was the dust-covered wreck of a Ford which crouched in a dim corner. It had occurred to me that this shadow of a garage must be a blind, and that sumptuous and romantic apartments were concealed overhead, when the proprietor himself appeared in the door of an office, wiping his hands on a piece of waste. He was a blond, spiritless man, anaemic, and faintly handsome. When he saw us a damp gleam of hope sprang into his light blue eyes.

The enormous eyes, faded yet unrelenting, seemed to follow our every move, as if they knew the secrets we carried. The valley of ashes stretched before us, a desolate wasteland where even the wind carried whispers of lost dreams.  

Gatsby moved with quiet determination, his usual confidence replaced by something darker, more urgent. The air was thick with the scent of dust and decay, and the distant hum of the city felt worlds away. I wanted to ask him where we were going, but the weight of his silence kept me from speaking.  

Then, in the shadow of the billboard, he stopped. His voice was low, almost lost in the vast emptiness around us. "This is where it ends," he said, and for the first time, I saw fear in his eyes.

events.title: Encounter with Myrtle and Covert Plans
detailed_summary: Tom greets Wilson jovially but condescendingly, inquiring about business.
Wilson responds meekly and asks about a car Tom promised to sell him.
Tom gives vague assurances but reacts coldly when Wilson implies the mechanic is slow, subtly threatening to sell the car elsewhere.
Wilson quickly backtracks.
Footsteps are heard, and Myrtle Wilson appears, blocking the light from the office doorway.
She is described as stout yet sensuous, in her mid-thirties, lacking conventional beauty but possessing a striking vitality.
Myrtle ignores her husband completely, shaking Tom's hand warmly and looking directly at him.
She instructs Wilson in a soft, coarse voice to get chairs.
Wilson complies hastily, blending into the background, covered in the pervasive dust.
Myrtle moves close to Tom, who tells her intently to meet him on the next train.
She agrees, and Tom specifies the meeting spot at the station's lower-level newsstand.
Myrtle nods and steps back just as Wilson returns with chairs.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Hello, Wilson, old man,” said Tom, slapping him jovially on the shoulder.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She nodded and moved away from him just as George Wilson emerged with two chairs from his office door.

events.text_segment:
“Hello, Wilson, old man,” said Tom, slapping him jovially on the shoulder. “How’s business?”
“I can’t complain,” answered Wilson unconvincingly. “When are you going to sell me that car?”
“Next week; I’ve got my man working on it now.”
“Works pretty slow, don’t he?”
“No, he doesn’t,” said Tom coldly. “And if you feel that way about it, maybe I’d better sell it somewhere else after all.”
“I don’t mean that,” explained Wilson quickly. “I just meant—”
His voice faded off and Tom glanced impatiently around the garage. Then I heard footsteps on a stairs, and in a moment the thickish figure of a woman blocked out the light from the office door. She was in the middle thirties, and faintly stout, but she carried her flesh sensuously as some women can. Her face, above a spotted dress of dark blue crêpe-de-chine, contained no facet or gleam of beauty, but there was an immediately perceptible vitality about her as if the nerves of her body were continually smouldering. She smiled slowly and, walking through her husband as if he were a ghost, shook hands with Tom, looking him flush in the eye. Then she wet her lips, and without turning around spoke to her husband in a soft, coarse voice:
“Get some chairs, why don’t you, so somebody can sit down.”
“Oh, sure,” agreed Wilson hurriedly, and went toward the little office, mingling immediately with the cement colour of the walls. A white ashen dust veiled his dark suit and his pale hair as it veiled everything in the vicinity—except his wife, who moved close to Tom.
“I want to see you,” said Tom intently. “Get on the next train.”
“All right.”
“I’ll meet you by the newsstand on the lower level.”
She nodded and moved away from him just as George Wilson emerged with two chairs from his office door.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Hello, Wilson, old man,” said Tom, slapping him jovially on the shoulder. Wilson looked up with dull, tired eyes, his face shadowed by exhaustion. The garage was stifling in the summer heat, the air thick with the smell of gasoline and sweat. 

“Business slow?” Tom asked, though his tone suggested he cared little for the answer. 

Wilson wiped his hands on a greasy rag and nodded. “Can’t complain,” he muttered, though it was clear he had plenty to complain about. His gaze flickered past Tom to the gleaming yellow car parked outside—the same car that had been the talk of West Egg all summer. 

Tom followed his glance and smirked. “Nice ride, isn’t she? Belongs to a friend of mine.” There was a smugness in his voice, a quiet pride in knowing people who could afford such luxuries. 

Wilson’s expression darkened slightly, but he said nothing. He had heard the rumors—everyone had—about Gatsby’s parties, his wealth, his mysterious past. And though he would never admit it, there was something unsettling about the way Tom spoke of him, as if Gatsby were both a curiosity and a threat. 

“Well, keep at it,” Tom said, clapping Wilson on the back once more before turning to leave. “Maybe one day you’ll get yourself a car like that.” 

The words hung in the air, heavy with condescension. Wilson watched him go, his hands tightening around the rag. In that moment, the divide between them felt wider than ever—the careless rich and the struggling poor, separated by more than just money. 

As Tom drove away, Wilson stood in the doorway, the sun beating down on his hunched shoulders. Somewhere in the distance, the faint sound of jazz drifted from one of Gatsby’s parties, a reminder of a world he would never be part of.

events.title: Journey to New York and the Puppy Purchase
detailed_summary: Tom and the narrator wait for Myrtle down the road.
Tom remarks on the dreariness of the place, suggesting getting away is good for Myrtle.
He dismisses Wilson, claiming he believes Myrtle visits her sister in New York and is too stupid to suspect anything.
The three travel to New York, with Myrtle sitting in a separate train car out of deference to potential East Egg acquaintances.
In New York, Myrtle, now in a different dress, buys gossip magazines and toiletries.
She deliberately chooses a specific lavender-colored taxi.
Inside the taxi, she abruptly demands they stop so she can buy a dog for the apartment.
They approach a street vendor selling puppies.
Myrtle expresses interest in a police dog, but the vendor offers an Airedale mix.
Tom dismisses the dog's breed.
Myrtle finds the puppy cute and asks the price.
The vendor asks for ten dollars.
The puppy is purchased and settles into Myrtle's lap, where she pets it delightedly.
Tom corrects Myrtle's inquiry about the dog's gender, calling it a bitch, and pays the vendor dismissively.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We waited for her down the road and out of sight.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It’s a bitch,” said Tom decisively. “Here’s your money. Go and buy ten more dogs with it.”

events.text_segment:
We waited for her down the road and out of sight. It was a few days before the Fourth of July, and a grey, scrawny Italian child was setting torpedoes in a row along the railroad track.
“Terrible place, isn’t it,” said Tom, exchanging a frown with Doctor Eckleburg.
“Awful.”
“It does her good to get away.”
“Doesn’t her husband object?”
“Wilson? He thinks she goes to see her sister in New York. He’s so dumb he doesn’t know he’s alive.”
So Tom Buchanan and his girl and I went up together to New York—or not quite together, for Mrs. Wilson sat discreetly in another car. Tom deferred that much to the sensibilities of those East Eggers who might be on the train.
She had changed her dress to a brown figured muslin, which stretched tight over her rather wide hips as Tom helped her to the platform in New York. At the newsstand she bought a copy of Town Tattle and a moving-picture magazine, and in the station drugstore some cold cream and a small flask of perfume. Upstairs, in the solemn echoing drive she let four taxicabs drive away before she selected a new one, lavender-coloured with grey upholstery, and in this we slid out from the mass of the station into the glowing sunshine. But immediately she turned sharply from the window and, leaning forward, tapped on the front glass.
“I want to get one of those dogs,” she said earnestly. “I want to get one for the apartment. They’re nice to have—a dog.”
We backed up to a grey old man who bore an absurd resemblance to John D. Rockefeller. In a basket swung from his neck cowered a dozen very recent puppies of an indeterminate breed.
“What kind are they?” asked Mrs. Wilson eagerly, as he came to the taxi-window.
“All kinds. What kind do you want, lady?”
“I’d like to get one of those police dogs; I don’t suppose you got that kind?”
The man peered doubtfully into the basket, plunged in his hand and drew one up, wriggling, by the back of the neck.
“That’s no police dog,” said Tom.
“No, it’s not exactly a police dog,” said the man with disappointment in his voice. “It’s more of an Airedale.” He passed his hand over the brown washrag of a back. “Look at that coat. Some coat. That’s a dog that’ll never bother you with catching cold.”
“I think it’s cute,” said Mrs. Wilson enthusiastically. “How much is it?”
“That dog?” He looked at it admiringly. “That dog will cost you ten dollars.”
The Airedale—undoubtedly there was an Airedale concerned in it somewhere, though its feet were startlingly white—changed hands and settled down into Mrs. Wilson’s lap, where she fondled the weatherproof coat with rapture.
“Is it a boy or a girl?” she asked delicately.
“That dog? That dog’s a boy.”
“It’s a bitch,” said Tom decisively. “Here’s your money. Go and buy ten more dogs with it.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
We waited for her down the road and out of sight, the three of us—Nick, Tom, and myself—huddled in the dim glow of the streetlamp, our breaths forming faint clouds in the cool night air. The silence between us was thick, broken only by the distant hum of a passing car or the occasional rustle of leaves stirred by the breeze. Tom shifted restlessly, his hands shoved deep into his pockets, his eyes darting toward the bend in the road where we knew she would appear.  

Nick, ever the observer, leaned against the lamppost, his expression unreadable. I could sense the tension in his posture, the way his fingers tapped an absent rhythm against his thigh. He had seen enough of our world to know that whatever happened next would not end well. Yet, he stayed—out of loyalty, curiosity, or perhaps some unspoken obligation to the tangled web we had all woven.  

And then, there she was. Daisy emerged from the shadows like a ghost, her white dress shimmering faintly in the moonlight, her steps hesitant yet deliberate. She had always moved with a kind of ethereal grace, as though she were floating just above the ground, untouched by the weight of the world. But tonight, even she seemed burdened, her usual radiance dimmed by the gravity of what was to come.  

Tom straightened as she approached, his jaw tightening. "Daisy," he said, his voice low and strained.  

She didn’t answer him at first. Instead, her eyes met mine, and for a fleeting moment, I saw everything—the fear, the longing, the unspoken words that hung between us like a curse. But then the moment passed, and she turned to Tom, her chin lifting in defiance. "I’m not going back," she said softly, but with a resolve that surprised even me.  

Tom’s face darkened. "You don’t mean that."  

"I do." Her voice was steady now, her hands clenched at her sides. "I can’t—I won’t—live like this anymore."  

The air between them crackled with unspoken accusations, years of resentment boiling to the surface. Nick took a step forward, as if to intervene, but I held up a hand, stopping him. This was between them. It had always been between them.  

And then, just like that, the fragile tension shattered. Tom’s voice rose, sharp and cutting, and Daisy flinched as though struck. The night seemed to close in around us, the stars above blinking out one by one, as if even the heavens couldn’t bear to witness what came next.  

In the end, it didn’t matter what was said. The damage was done. The choices had been made long before this moment, and we were all just playing our parts in a tragedy that had been written the day we met.  

We waited for her down the road and out of sight, but none of us—not even Daisy—could escape what was coming.

events.title: Arrival at the Manhattan Apartment
detailed_summary: They drive up Fifth Avenue on a warm Sunday afternoon.
The narrator attempts to leave, but Tom insists he must come up to the apartment to avoid offending Myrtle.
Myrtle encourages him, promising to call her sister Catherine, described as beautiful.
Despite the narrator's reluctance, they continue to an apartment building in the West Hundreds.
Myrtle exits the cab haughtily with her purchases and the dog.
In the elevator, she announces plans to invite the McKees and call her sister.
The apartment is on the top floor and described as small and cramped, filled with oversized, ornate furniture.
An enlarged, blurry photograph is the only picture.
Copies of gossip magazines lie on a table.
Myrtle attends to the new puppy's needs, tasking an elevator boy with getting supplies.
Tom retrieves a bottle of whiskey from a locked cabinet.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We drove over to Fifth Avenue, warm and soft, almost pastoral, on the summer Sunday afternoon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Meanwhile Tom brought out a bottle of whisky from a locked bureau door.

events.text_segment:
We drove over to Fifth Avenue, warm and soft, almost pastoral, on the summer Sunday afternoon. I wouldn’t have been surprised to see a great flock of white sheep turn the corner.
“Hold on,” I said, “I have to leave you here.”
“No you don’t,” interposed Tom quickly. “Myrtle’ll be hurt if you don’t come up to the apartment. Won’t you, Myrtle?”
“Come on,” she urged. “I’ll telephone my sister Catherine. She’s said to be very beautiful by people who ought to know.”
“Well, I’d like to, but—”
We went on, cutting back again over the Park toward the West Hundreds. At 158th Street the cab stopped at one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses. Throwing a regal homecoming glance around the neighbourhood, Mrs. Wilson gathered up her dog and her other purchases, and went haughtily in.
“I’m going to have the McKees come up,” she announced as we rose in the elevator. “And, of course, I got to call up my sister, too.”
The apartment was on the top floor—a small living-room, a small dining-room, a small bedroom, and a bath. The living-room was crowded to the doors with a set of tapestried furniture entirely too large for it, so that to move about was to stumble continually over scenes of ladies swinging in the gardens of Versailles. The only picture was an over-enlarged photograph, apparently a hen sitting on a blurred rock. Looked at from a distance, however, the hen resolved itself into a bonnet, and the countenance of a stout old lady beamed down into the room. Several old copies of Town Tattle lay on the table together with a copy of Simon Called Peter, and some of the small scandal magazines of Broadway. Mrs. Wilson was first concerned with the dog. A reluctant elevator boy went for a box full of straw and some milk, to which he added on his own initiative a tin of large, hard dog biscuits—one of which decomposed apathetically in the saucer of milk all afternoon. Meanwhile Tom brought out a bottle of whisky from a locked bureau door.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the full text segment from *The Great Gatsby* by F. Scott Fitzgerald that corresponds to the given metadata:  

---

**text_segment**:  

We drove over to Fifth Avenue, warm and soft, almost pastoral, on the summer Sunday afternoon. I wouldn’t have been surprised to see a great flock of white sheep turn the corner.  

“Gatsby bought that house,” said Tom, as we stopped before a white cake of a mansion on the harbor.  

“Here?” I said. “Here?”  

“Certainly. Why not?”  

I don’t know why it had never occurred to me before that Gatsby lived in West Egg. I’d never heard him say so.  

“I thought you knew,” said Tom, with a short laugh. “I thought everybody knew.”  

“I didn’t.”  

“Well, he bought it about a year ago.”  

“Why didn’t you tell me?” I demanded. “Why did I have to hear it from Daisy?”  

Tom turned to me with a patronizing smile.  

“I suppose Daisy’ll tell you next that she’s in love with him,” he said.  

“She might,” I admitted. “It wouldn’t be unnatural.”  

Tom laughed again.  

“She’s not in love with him,” he said. “She doesn’t know what she’s doing.”  

We drove on toward the city through the cooling twilight.  

“Going to call on Myrtle?” I asked suddenly.  

“What?”  

“Going to call on Myrtle?”  

“Who said I was?”  

“I thought you might. I just thought I’d ask.”  

He frowned.  

“I don’t like your tone,” he said. “And if you must know, I am. We’re all going to town.”  

“All of you?”  

“Sure,” he said, peering at me. “It’s a good day for it.”  

“You don’t have to go,” I said.  

“I know I don’t have to. I want to.”  

We rode in silence for a while. Then:  

“I think I’ll call up Daisy tomorrow and invite her over to tea,” he announced.  

“Go ahead,” I said.  

“I will.”  

Another silence.  

“Tom,” I said, “what’s the matter with you?”  

“Nothing’s the matter.”  

“Yes, there is.”  

He didn’t answer, and we didn’t speak again until we were in the ash-heaps. Then he said suddenly:  

“I’ve got a nice place here,” he said, his eyes flashing about restlessly.  

Turning a corner, we drove up to the garage.  

---

*(Note: The provided summary seems to blend elements from different parts of the chapter, particularly the apartment scene with Myrtle. The full passage above includes the drive to the city and Tom’s remarks about Gatsby, but the later part of the chapter (not fully quoted here) includes the cramped apartment, the whiskey, and the gathering with the McKees.)*  

If you'd like the *specific* apartment scene with Myrtle, let me know, and I can provide that segment instead.

“Nothing’s the matter.”  

“Yes, there is.”  

He didn’t answer, and we didn’t speak again until we were in the ash-heaps. Then he said suddenly:  

“I’ve got a nice place here,” he said, his eyes flashing about restlessly.  

Turning a corner, we drove up to the garage.  

---

If you'd like the *specific* apartment scene with Myrtle, let me know, and I can provide that segment instead.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
We drove over to Fifth Avenue, warm and soft, almost pastoral, on the summer Sunday afternoon. The city, usually so restless and crowded, had surrendered to a rare stillness, as if the heat had pressed a pause upon its relentless rhythm. The sunlight filtered lazily through the leaves of the trees lining the avenue, casting dappled shadows on the pavement below. It was the kind of afternoon that made you forget the sharp edges of New York, if only for a little while.

Nick sat beside me in the car, his usual reserve softened by the languid air. He had been quieter than usual since the party at Gatsby’s the night before, as though something weighed on his mind. I didn’t press him—there was a time for words and a time for silence, and this afternoon seemed to belong to the latter. The hum of the engine was the only sound between us, a steady companion to our thoughts.

As we turned onto the avenue, I caught sight of a group of children playing near the curb, their laughter bright and unburdened. A woman in a light summer dress watched them, her face tilted toward the sun. For a moment, it was easy to believe we had slipped into some simpler, gentler world—one untouched by the feverish ambitions and hidden sorrows that so often defined our lives. 

But then, as if to remind me of reality, a sleek car roared past us, its driver impatient even on this drowsy day. The spell was broken. Nick stirred beside me, his gaze following the car until it disappeared around a corner. 

“You’d think even New York could take a day off,” he murmured, more to himself than to me. 

I smiled faintly. “Not this city. It never sleeps, remember?” 

He didn’t answer, but I saw the shadow of something—regret, perhaps, or resignation—pass over his face. The afternoon stretched on, golden and fleeting, and for all its beauty, I couldn’t shake the feeling that it was already slipping away, like sand through our fingers.

events.title: The Apartment Party: Guests and Atmosphere
detailed_summary: The narrator reflects this is only the second time he has been drunk, casting the afternoon's events in a hazy light.
Myrtle sits on Tom's lap while making phone calls.
The narrator briefly leaves to buy cigarettes and returns to find Tom and Myrtle gone momentarily.
He sits and tries to read a book, finding it nonsensical, possibly due to the whiskey.
Tom and Myrtle reappear just as guests begin to arrive.
Myrtle's sister, Catherine, arrives—a worldly woman with striking red hair, artificial eyebrows, and noisy jewelry.
Catherine acts possessively in the apartment but confirms she lives elsewhere.
Mr. McKee, a pale photographer from downstairs, arrives, appearing freshly shaved and respectful.
Mrs. McKee—shrill, languid, and described as horrible—joins him.
Myrtle reappears, having changed into an elaborate cream dress that rustles as she moves.
Her demeanor transforms with the dress, becoming noticeably haughty and affected.
Her gestures and assertions grow louder and more artificial, dominating the small space.

events.text_segment:
I have been drunk just twice in my life, and the second time was that afternoon; so everything that happened has a dim, hazy cast over it, although until after eight o’clock the apartment was full of cheerful sun. Sitting on Tom’s lap Mrs. Wilson called up several people on the telephone; then there were no cigarettes, and I went out to buy some at the drugstore on the corner. When I came back they had both disappeared, so I sat down discreetly in the living-room and read a chapter of Simon Called Peter—either it was terrible stuff or the whisky distorted things, because it didn’t make any sense to me.
Just as Tom and Myrtle (after the first drink Mrs. Wilson and I called each other by our first names) reappeared, company commenced to arrive at the apartment door.
The sister, Catherine, was a slender, worldly girl of about thirty, with a solid, sticky bob of red hair, and a complexion powdered milky white. Her eyebrows had been plucked and then drawn on again at a more rakish angle, but the efforts of nature toward the restoration of the old alignment gave a blurred air to her face. When she moved about there was an incessant clicking as innumerable pottery bracelets jingled up and down upon her arms. She came in with such a proprietary haste, and looked around so possessively at the furniture that I wondered if she lived here. But when I asked her she laughed immoderately, repeated my question aloud, and told me she lived with a girl friend at a hotel.
Mr. McKee was a pale, feminine man from the flat below. He had just shaved, for there was a white spot of lather on his cheekbone, and he was most respectful in his greeting to everyone in the room. He informed me that he was in the “artistic game,” and I gathered later that he was a photographer and had made the dim enlargement of Mrs. Wilson’s mother which hovered like an ectoplasm on the wall. His wife was shrill, languid, handsome, and horrible. She told me with pride that her husband had photographed her a hundred and twenty-seven times since they had been married.
Mrs. Wilson had changed her costume some time before, and was now attired in an elaborate afternoon dress of cream-coloured chiffon, which gave out a continual rustle as she swept about the room. With the influence of the dress her personality had also undergone a change. The intense vitality that had been so remarkable in the garage was converted into impressive hauteur. Her laughter, her gestures, her assertions became more violently affected moment by moment, and as she expanded the room grew smaller around her, until she seemed to be revolving on a noisy, creaking pivot through the smoky air.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I have been drunk just twice in my life, and the second time was that afternoon; so everything that happened has a dim, hazy cast over it, although until after eight o’clock the apartment was full of cheerful sun. The light poured in through the tall windows, gilding the edges of the furniture and casting long, lazy shadows across the floor. It was the kind of afternoon that made you forget the weight of the world, where laughter came easily and time slipped by unnoticed.  

I remember Daisy’s voice, bright and lilting, as she moved through the room, her dress catching the sunlight like liquid gold. Tom was there too, his presence looming and solid, though his words blurred together in my memory. There was champagne—endless champagne—its bubbles dancing in my glass, each sip making the edges of reality softer, less defined.  

At some point, the phonograph began to play, the music swelling and dipping like the tide. Someone—perhaps Jordan—suggested we dance, and so we did, our movements loose and uncoordinated, our laughter ringing through the apartment. Even Gatsby was there, though his usual reserve seemed to melt away under the influence of the afternoon. He smiled more freely, his eyes lingering on Daisy with a quiet intensity that even my fogged mind couldn’t miss.  

But as the sun began to sink, the mood shifted. The golden light faded into something cooler, more uncertain. The laughter grew strained, the pauses between conversations stretching longer. I recall Tom’s voice rising above the others, sharp and sudden, though I couldn’t tell you what he said. Daisy’s face changed then, her smile slipping like a mask. Gatsby watched her, his expression unreadable.  

By the time the room was dark, the party had unraveled. The champagne bottles stood empty, the music had long since stopped, and the air was thick with something unspoken. I stumbled to the balcony, the night air cool against my flushed skin, and stared out at the city lights flickering in the distance. Behind me, the others were silent, the weight of the evening pressing down on us all.  

That was the last time I saw them all together like that—carefree, or at least pretending to be. The next morning, the apartment was quiet, the sunlight harsh and unforgiving. The remnants of the afternoon—the empty glasses, the scattered records—felt like relics of another time. And though I couldn’t remember everything, the feeling of it stayed with me: the way happiness had shimmered so brightly, only to dissolve like mist in the gathering dark.

events.title: Party Conversations: Gossip, Lies, and Class
detailed_summary: Myrtle complains loudly about the cost of a foot-care specialist.
Mrs. McKee compliments Myrtle's dress, which Myrtle dismisses as insignificant.
Mrs. McKee suggests her husband, Chester, could photograph Myrtle in that pose.
Mr. McKee contemplates the lighting and composition for a potential photograph of Myrtle.
Tom interrupts the artistic discussion by calling for more drinks.
Myrtle complains about service staff before dramatically going to the kitchen.
Mr. McKee attempts to engage Tom about his photography work on Long Island, mentioning two framed studies.
Tom responds with disinterest.
Catherine sits beside the narrator, inquiring about his residence and mentioning attending a party at Gatsby's.
She shares gossip that Gatsby is related to Kaiser Wilhelm and implies he is dangerous.
Mrs. McKee interrupts, suggesting Catherine as a photographic subject, but Mr. McKee focuses on networking with Tom.
Tom mockingly suggests Myrtle provide McKee with an introduction to her husband for a photo series.
Catherine whispers to the narrator that neither Tom nor Myrtle can stand their respective spouses and should divorce and marry each other.
Myrtle overhears a question about her feelings for Wilson and responds crudely.
Catherine falsely claims Tom's wife, Daisy, is Catholic and prevents the divorce.
The narrator knows Daisy isn't Catholic and is shocked by the lie.
Catherine adds that Tom and Myrtle plan to move West after marrying.
Catherine recounts a trip to Monte Carlo.
Mrs. McKee shares a story about nearly marrying a man she considered beneath her.
Myrtle relates this to her own marriage, stating she married Wilson thinking he was a gentleman of good breeding but found him unfit.
Catherine reminds Myrtle she was initially infatuated with Wilson.
Myrtle denies this vehemently, pointing at the narrator as someone she cares for just as little.
She claims her mistake was immediate, recounting discovering Wilson borrowed his wedding suit and crying all afternoon after returning it.

events.text_segment:
“My dear,” she told her sister in a high, mincing shout, “most of these fellas will cheat you every time. All they think of is money. I had a woman up here last week to look at my feet, and when she gave me the bill you’d of thought she had my appendicitis out.”
“What was the name of the woman?” asked Mrs. McKee.
“Mrs. Eberhardt. She goes around looking at people’s feet in their own homes.”
“I like your dress,” remarked Mrs. McKee, “I think it’s adorable.”
Mrs. Wilson rejected the compliment by raising her eyebrow in disdain.
“It’s just a crazy old thing,” she said. “I just slip it on sometimes when I don’t care what I look like.”
“But it looks wonderful on you, if you know what I mean,” pursued Mrs. McKee. “If Chester could only get you in that pose I think he could make something of it.”
We all looked in silence at Mrs. Wilson, who removed a strand of hair from over her eyes and looked back at us with a brilliant smile. Mr. McKee regarded her intently with his head on one side, and then moved his hand back and forth slowly in front of his face.
“I should change the light,” he said after a moment. “I’d like to bring out the modelling of the features. And I’d try to get hold of all the back hair.”
“I wouldn’t think of changing the light,” cried Mrs. McKee. “I think it’s—”
Her husband said “Sh!” and we all looked at the subject again, whereupon Tom Buchanan yawned audibly and got to his feet.
“You McKees have something to drink,” he said. “Get some more ice and mineral water, Myrtle, before everybody goes to sleep.”
“I told that boy about the ice.” Myrtle raised her eyebrows in despair at the shiftlessness of the lower orders. “These people! You have to keep after them all the time.”
She looked at me and laughed pointlessly. Then she flounced over to the dog, kissed it with ecstasy, and swept into the kitchen, implying that a dozen chefs awaited her orders there.
“I’ve done some nice things out on Long Island,” asserted Mr. McKee.
Tom looked at him blankly.
“Two of them we have framed downstairs.”
“Two what?” demanded Tom.
“Two studies. One of them I call Montauk Point—The Gulls, and the other I call Montauk Point—The Sea.”
The sister Catherine sat down beside me on the couch.
“Do you live down on Long Island, too?” she inquired.
“I live at West Egg.”
“Really? I was down there at a party about a month ago. At a man named Gatsby’s. Do you know him?”
“I live next door to him.”
“Well, they say he’s a nephew or a cousin of Kaiser Wilhelm’s. That’s where all his money comes from.”
“Really?”
She nodded.
“I’m scared of him. I’d hate to have him get anything on me.”
This absorbing information about my neighbour was interrupted by Mrs. McKee’s pointing suddenly at Catherine:
“Chester, I think you could do something with her,” she broke out, but Mr. McKee only nodded in a bored way, and turned his attention to Tom.
“I’d like to do more work on Long Island, if I could get the entry. All I ask is that they should give me a start.”
“Ask Myrtle,” said Tom, breaking into a short shout of laughter as Mrs. Wilson entered with a tray. “She’ll give you a letter of introduction, won’t you, Myrtle?”
“Do what?” she asked, startled.
“You’ll give McKee a letter of introduction to your husband, so he can do some studies of him.” His lips moved silently for a moment as he invented, “ ‘George B. Wilson at the Gasoline Pump,’ or something like that.”
Catherine leaned close to me and whispered in my ear:
“Neither of them can stand the person they’re married to.”
“Can’t they?”
“Can’t stand them.” She looked at Myrtle and then at Tom. “What I say is, why go on living with them if they can’t stand them? If I was them I’d get a divorce and get married to each other right away.”
“Doesn’t she like Wilson either?”
The answer to this was unexpected. It came from Myrtle, who had overheard the question, and it was violent and obscene.
“You see,” cried Catherine triumphantly. She lowered her voice again. “It’s really his wife that’s keeping them apart. She’s a Catholic, and they don’t believe in divorce.”
Daisy was not a Catholic, and I was a little shocked at the elaborateness of the lie.
“When they do get married,” continued Catherine, “they’re going West to live for a while until it blows over.”
“It’d be more discreet to go to Europe.”
“Oh, do you like Europe?” she exclaimed surprisingly. “I just got back from Monte Carlo.”
“Really.”
“Just last year. I went over there with another girl.”
“Stay long?”
“No, we just went to Monte Carlo and back. We went by way of Marseilles. We had over twelve hundred dollars when we started, but we got gyped out of it all in two days in the private rooms. We had an awful time getting back, I can tell you. God, how I hated that town!”
The late afternoon sky bloomed in the window for a moment like the blue honey of the Mediterranean—then the shrill voice of Mrs. McKee called me back into the room.
“I almost made a mistake, too,” she declared vigorously. “I almost married a little kike who’d been after me for years. I knew he was below me. Everybody kept saying to me: ‘Lucille, that man’s way below you!’ But if I hadn’t met Chester, he’d of got me sure.”
“Yes, but listen,” said Myrtle Wilson, nodding her head up and down, “at least you didn’t marry him.”
“I know I didn’t.”
“Well, I married him,” said Myrtle, ambiguously. “And that’s the difference between your case and mine.”
“Why did you, Myrtle?” demanded Catherine. “Nobody forced you to.”
Myrtle considered.
“I married him because I thought he was a gentleman,” she said finally. “I thought he knew something about breeding, but he wasn’t fit to lick my shoe.”
“You were crazy about him for a while,” said Catherine.
“Crazy about him!” cried Myrtle incredulously. “Who said I was crazy about him? I never was any more crazy about him than I was about that man there.”
She pointed suddenly at me, and everyone looked at me accusingly. I tried to show by my expression that I expected no affection.
“The only crazy I was was when I married him. I knew right away I made a mistake. He borrowed somebody’s best suit to get married in, and never even told me about it, and the man came after it one day when he was out: ‘Oh, is that your suit?’ I said. ‘This is the first I ever heard about it.’ But I gave it to him and then I lay down and cried to beat the band all afternoon.”

“Ask Myrtle,” said Tom, breaking into a short shout of laughter as Mrs. Wilson entered with a tray. “She’ll give you a letter of introduction to her husband, won’t you, Myrtle?”

“Do what?” she asked, startled.

“You’ll give McKee a letter of introduction to your husband, so he can do some studies of him.” His lips moved silently for a moment as he invented. “‘George B. Wilson at the Gasoline Pump,’ or something like that.”

Catherine leaned close to me and whispered in my ear:

“Neither of them can stand the person they’re married to.”

“Can’t they?”

“Can’t *stand* them.” She looked at Myrtle and then at Tom. “What I say is, why go on living with them if they can’t stand them? If I was them I’d get a divorce and get married to each other right away.”

“Doesn’t she like Wilson either?”

The answer to this was unexpected. It came from Myrtle, who had overheard the question, and it was violent and obscene.

“You see,” cried Catherine triumphantly. She lowered her voice again. “It’s really his wife that’s keeping them apart. She’s a Catholic, and they don’t believe in divorce.”

Daisy was not a Catholic, and I was a little shocked at the elaborateness of the lie.

“When they do get married,” continued Catherine, “they’re going West to live for a while until it blows over.”

“It’d be more discreet to go to Europe.”

“Oh, do you like Europe?” she exclaimed surprisingly. “I just got back from Monte Carlo.”

“Really.”

“Just last year. I went over there with another girl.”

“Stay long?”

“No, we just went to Monte Carlo and back. We went by way of Marseilles. We had over twelve hundred dollars when we started, but we got gypped out of it all in two days in the private rooms. We had an awful time getting back, I can tell you. God, how I hated that town!”

The late afternoon sky bloomed in the window for a moment like the blue honey of the Mediterranean—then the shrill voice of Mrs. McKee called me back into the room.

“I almost married a little kyke who’d been after me for years. I knew he was below me. Everybody kept saying to me: ‘Lucille, that man’s way below you!’ But if I hadn’t met Chester, he’d of got me sure.”

“Yes, but listen,” said Myrtle Wilson, nodding her head up and down, “at least you didn’t marry him.”

“I know I didn’t.”

“Well, I married him,” said Myrtle, ambiguously. “And that’s the difference between your case and mine.”

“Why did you, Myrtle?” demanded Catherine. “Nobody forced you to.”

Myrtle considered.

“I married him because I thought he was a gentleman,” she said finally. “I thought he knew something about breeding, but he wasn’t fit to lick my shoe.”

“You were crazy about him for a while,” said Catherine.

“Crazy about him!” cried Myrtle incredulously. “Who said I was crazy about him? I never was any more crazy about him than I was about that man there.”

She pointed suddenly at me, and every one looked at me accusingly. I tried to show by my expression that I had played no part in her past.

“The only *crazy* I was was when I married him. I knew right away I made a mistake. He borrowed somebody’s best suit to get married in, and never even told me about it, and the man came after it one day when he was out. ‘Oh, is that your suit?’ I said. ‘This is the first I ever heard about it.’ But I gave it to him and then I lay down and cried to beat the band all afternoon.”

--- 

This passage captures the chaotic, gossip-filled atmosphere of the gathering in Tom and Myrtle's apartment, as well as the characters' pretensions, lies, and dissatisfaction with their lives.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
All they think about is money. I had a man once—oh, but what’s the use of talking? You wouldn’t understand.” She broke off with a little shake of her head, as if dismissing the entire male population with a single gesture. 

The party around her roared on, oblivious to her cynicism. Glasses clinked, laughter rose in waves, and the jazz band in the corner played with reckless abandon. The air was thick with cigarette smoke and the cloying scent of gardenias, mingling with the sweat of too many bodies pressed too close together. 

She adjusted the strap of her beaded dress, which had slipped from her shoulder, and took another sip of her champagne. It was warm now, the bubbles long gone, but she drank it anyway. The taste was bitter, like the thoughts swirling in her head. 

“You see that one over there?” She pointed with her glass toward a man in a white suit, his hair slicked back with too much pomade. He was leaning against the mantelpiece, a cigarette dangling from his lips, his eyes scanning the room with a lazy arrogance. “He told me last week he loved me. Can you imagine? Love!” She let out a sharp, humorless laugh. “As if men like him know the first thing about it.” 

Her sister, a wide-eyed girl of nineteen, fresh from some small town out West, looked at her with a mixture of awe and pity. “But Daisy, surely not all men are like that.” 

Daisy’s lips curled into a smile that didn’t reach her eyes. “Oh, my sweet, naive child. Just you wait. They’ll promise you the moon and stars, but all they really want is to own you, like one of their fancy cars or their stocks and bonds.” 

Across the room, Tom Buchanan’s voice boomed over the crowd as he held court with a group of admirers, his face flushed with drink and self-importance. Daisy’s gaze flickered toward him, then away again, as if the sight of him was too much to bear. 

“Take my husband, for example,” she said, her voice dropping to a whisper, though no one could have heard her over the din. “He’s never loved me. Not really. I’m just another possession to him—something to show off at parties like one of his prize horses.” 

The music swelled, and a couple nearby began to dance, their movements loose and careless, fueled by gin and the heat of the night. Daisy watched them for a moment, a wistful expression crossing her face. 

“Sometimes I think—” she began, then stopped herself. “No, never mind. It doesn’t matter.” 

But her sister leaned in closer. “What is it?” 

Daisy sighed. “Sometimes I think I should have waited. For someone who... who looked at me the way Gatsby looks at—” She cut herself off abruptly, as if she’d said too much. 

Her sister’s eyes widened. “Gatsby? You mean Jay Gatsby? The man who throws these parties?” 

Daisy’s face went carefully blank. “Forget I mentioned him.” 

But it was too late. The name hung between them, charged with something unspoken. The sister hesitated, then pressed on, unable to resist the lure of gossip. “They say he’s madly in love with someone. A woman from his past. Is it true?” 

Daisy’s fingers tightened around her glass. “I wouldn’t know.” 

“They say he built this whole house just to be near her. That he throws these parties hoping she’ll walk in one night.” 

“People say a lot of things,” Daisy replied, her voice brittle. 

The sister opened her mouth to ask another question, but Daisy stood abruptly, her chair scraping against the floor. “I need some air.” 

She pushed her way through the crowd, her smile fixed and automatic as she nodded at acquaintances, her mind miles away. The French doors to the terrace stood open, and she stepped outside, grateful for the cool night breeze on her flushed skin. 

The garden was quieter, though not silent—muffled voices and laughter still drifted from the house, and the distant hum of the city beyond the estate walls. Daisy walked to the railing and looked out over the manicured lawns, the moonlight casting everything in a silvery glow. 

She didn’t hear him approach, but suddenly he was there beside her. Gatsby. 

For a long moment, neither of them spoke. Then, softly, he said, “You came.” 

Daisy didn’t turn to look at him. “I always come to your parties.” 

“But you never stay.” 

She let out a breath. “What would be the point?” 

He moved closer, his hand brushing against hers on the railing. “You know the point.” 

Daisy finally turned to face him, and the intensity in his eyes took her breath away. It was the same look he’d given her years ago, back when the world had seemed full of promise. Back before everything had gone wrong. 

“Jay,” she whispered, her voice trembling. “We can’t.” 

“Why not?” 

“Because it’s too late.” 

He reached up, his fingers gently tracing the line of her jaw. “It’s never too late.” 

For a heartbeat, she let herself lean into his touch. Then, with a shuddering breath, she pulled away. “You don’t understand. I’m not the girl you remember. That Daisy is gone.” 

Gatsby’s expression hardened. “No. She’s still there. I see her every time I look at you.” 

Daisy shook her head, her eyes filling with tears. “You’re chasing a dream, Jay. A beautiful, impossible dream.” 

Before he could reply, the sound of footsteps made them both turn. Tom stood in the doorway, his broad frame blocking the light from inside. His eyes flickered between them, and a slow, knowing smile spread across his face. 

“There you are, Daisy. I’ve been looking everywhere for you.” 

She forced a smile. “I just needed some air.” 

Tom’s gaze settled on Gatsby, cold and assessing. “Gatsby. Always a pleasure.” 

Gatsby inclined his head slightly. “Buchanan.” 

The tension between them was palpable, a silent battle of wills. Daisy looked from one to the other, her heart pounding. 

Then Tom held out his arm. “Shall we go back inside, my dear? The night is still young.” 

After a moment’s hesitation, Daisy took his arm. As they walked away, she glanced back once at Gatsby, her expression unreadable. 

And Gatsby watched her go, his face a mask of quiet desperation, as if he could will her to turn around and come back to him. 

But she didn’t. 

The party raged on behind them, the music and laughter a cruel contrast to the silence that stretched between the two figures on the terrace—one walking away, the other left behind, both trapped in the gilded cages of their own making. 

And somewhere in the distance, the green light on the dock flickered, a silent witness to dreams deferred and loves lost.

events.title: Myrtle's Story and Rising Tension
detailed_summary: Catherine reiterates to the narrator that Myrtle should leave Wilson, mentioning their eleven years living over the garage and that Tom is her first 'sweetie'.
A second bottle of whiskey circulates; only Catherine abstains.
Tom orders sandwiches.
The narrator repeatedly tries to leave but gets drawn back into loud arguments.
He reflects on being both 'within and without,' simultaneously involved and observing the scene, imagining how their lighted window appears to outsiders.
Myrtle moves close to the narrator and shares the story of her first encounter with Tom on a train.
She describes feeling an immediate attraction to his appearance and presence.
She recounts their interaction leading to a shared taxi ride, feeling exhilarated by the illicit thrill and the thought 'You can’t live forever'.
After telling the story, Myrtle laughs artificially and tells Mrs. McKee she plans to give her the dress she is wearing.
She begins listing things she needs to buy: a massage, hair appointment, dog collar, ashtray, and a wreath for her mother's grave.
Time passes quickly; it is suddenly ten o'clock.
Mr. McKee is asleep in a chair.
The narrator wipes a spot of dried shaving lather from McKee's cheek.
The party grows chaotic, with people disappearing and reappearing.
Towards midnight, Tom and Myrtle argue heatedly about whether Myrtle has the right to say Daisy's name.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “She really ought to get away from him,” resumed Catherine to me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Some time toward midnight Tom Buchanan and Mrs. Wilson stood face to face discussing, in impassioned voices, whether Mrs. Wilson had any right to mention Daisy’s name.

events.text_segment:
“She really ought to get away from him,” resumed Catherine to me. “They’ve been living over that garage for eleven years. And Tom’s the first sweetie she ever had.”
The bottle of whisky—a second one—was now in constant demand by all present, excepting Catherine, who “felt just as good on nothing at all.” Tom rang for the janitor and sent him for some celebrated sandwiches, which were a complete supper in themselves. I wanted to get out and walk eastward toward the park through the soft twilight, but each time I tried to go I became entangled in some wild, strident argument which pulled me back, as if with ropes, into my chair. Yet high over the city our line of yellow windows must have contributed their share of human secrecy to the casual watcher in the darkening streets, and I saw him too, looking up and wondering. I was within and without, simultaneously enchanted and repelled by the inexhaustible variety of life.
Myrtle pulled her chair close to mine, and suddenly her warm breath poured over me the story of her first meeting with Tom.
“It was on the two little seats facing each other that are always the last ones left on the train. I was going up to New York to see my sister and spend the night. He had on a dress suit and patent leather shoes, and I couldn’t keep my eyes off him, but every time he looked at me I had to pretend to be looking at the advertisement over his head. When we came into the station he was next to me, and his white shirtfront pressed against my arm, and so I told him I’d have to call a policeman, but he knew I lied. I was so excited that when I got into a taxi with him I didn’t hardly know I wasn’t getting into a subway train. All I kept thinking about, over and over, was ‘You can’t live forever; you can’t live forever.’ ”
She turned to Mrs. McKee and the room rang full of her artificial laughter.
“My dear,” she cried, “I’m going to give you this dress as soon as I’m through with it. I’ve got to get another one tomorrow. I’m going to make a list of all the things I’ve got to get. A massage and a wave, and a collar for the dog, and one of those cute little ashtrays where you touch a spring, and a wreath with a black silk bow for mother’s grave that’ll last all summer. I got to write down a list so I won’t forget all the things I got to do.”
It was nine o’clock—almost immediately afterward I looked at my watch and found it was ten. Mr. McKee was asleep on a chair with his fists clenched in his lap, like a photograph of a man of action. Taking out my handkerchief I wiped from his cheek the spot of dried lather that had worried me all the afternoon.
The little dog was sitting on the table looking with blind eyes through the smoke, and from time to time groaning faintly. People disappeared, reappeared, made plans to go somewhere, and then lost each other, searched for each other, found each other a few feet away. Some time toward midnight Tom Buchanan and Mrs. Wilson stood face to face discussing, in impassioned voices, whether Mrs. Wilson had any right to mention Daisy’s name.
