LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I had them both on their feet with the desperate suggestion that they help me make tea in the kitchen when the demoniac Finn brought it in on a tray. The tension in the room was unbearable—Tom’s smoldering anger, Daisy’s nervous laughter, Gatsby’s quiet desperation—all of it pressing against the walls like a storm about to break. The arrival of the tea was a reprieve, however brief, from the suffocating atmosphere.  

Finn, the wild-eyed servant with a face like a storm cloud, set the tray down with a clatter that made Daisy jump. The china rattled, the silver spoons chimed against the saucers, and for a moment, the absurdity of it all struck me—here we were, pretending at civility while the air crackled with unspoken accusations.  

“Thank you,” Daisy murmured, her voice barely above a whisper, as if she feared speaking too loudly might shatter the fragile peace. She reached for the teapot, her fingers trembling slightly, and I noticed how Gatsby’s eyes followed her every movement. There was something tragic in the way he watched her, as though she were already slipping through his fingers.  

Tom, ever the brute, seized his cup without waiting to be served, sloshing tea over the rim in his haste. “Well,” he said, his voice dripping with false cheer, “this is cozy, isn’t it?” His eyes flicked between Gatsby and Daisy, daring one of them to react.  

Gatsby, to his credit, remained composed, though I could see the strain in the tight line of his jaw. “Quite,” he replied evenly, lifting his own cup with deliberate calm.  

The silence stretched, thick and heavy, until Daisy let out a strained laugh. “Oh, Nick, you must think we’re all dreadfully dull today.”  

Before I could respond, Tom cut in. “I don’t think Nick cares much one way or the other. Isn’t that right, old sport?” He turned his gaze on me, challenging, and I realized with a sinking feeling that I had been dragged into their battle whether I liked it or not.  

“I think,” I said carefully, “that everyone could use a moment to breathe.”  

Tom snorted. “Breathe? Is that what we’re calling it now?” His eyes locked onto Gatsby. “Tell me, Gatsby—or whatever your real name is—how exactly does a man like you come into so much money?”  

The question hung in the air like a guillotine’s blade. Daisy’s breath hitched, her eyes darting between the two men. Gatsby, however, didn’t flinch.  

“That,” he said coolly, “is hardly your concern.”  

Tom’s face darkened. “Oh, but I think it is. Especially when you’re sniffing around my wife.”  

Daisy made a small, distressed noise. “Tom, please—”  

“No, Daisy, I think it’s time we had this out in the open.” Tom set his cup down with a sharp click. “This man is a fraud. A bootlegger, at best. And you—” He turned on Gatsby, his voice rising. “You think you can just waltz in here and take what’s mine?”  

Gatsby’s composure cracked then, just for an instant. A flash of raw emotion—anger, desperation, something deeper—crossed his face before he schooled it back into calm. “Daisy isn’t yours to keep,” he said quietly.  

The room seemed to tilt. Daisy’s hands flew to her mouth, her eyes wide with shock. Tom let out a bark of laughter, but there was no humor in it.  

“Oh, that’s rich,” he sneered. “You really believe that, don’t you? That she’d choose you?”  

Gatsby didn’t answer, but the look in his eyes was answer enough.  

And then, as if the universe itself had decided to intervene, the phone rang.  

The shrill sound cut through the tension like a knife. For a moment, no one moved. Then, with a muttered curse, Tom stalked out of the room to answer it.  

The silence he left behind was deafening. Daisy’s breath came in shallow gasps, her face pale. Gatsby reached for her hand, but she pulled away, her eyes darting toward the doorway where Tom had disappeared.  

“Daisy—” Gatsby began, but she shook her head.  

“I can’t,” she whispered. “Not like this.”  

And just like that, the fragile hope in Gatsby’s eyes shattered.  

The tea grew cold, untouched. The afternoon light slanted through the windows, casting long shadows across the floor. Somewhere in the distance, a car engine roared to life.  

And I realized, with a sinking heart, that the dream was already over.

events.title: Touring the Mansion: Wealth, History, and Emotion
detailed_summary: While Daisy goes upstairs to freshen up, Gatsby proudly points out his house to Nick, asking if it looks well.
He claims it took him only three years to earn the money to buy it.
When Nick questions this, reminding Gatsby he'd said he inherited his money, Gatsby automatically confirms the inheritance but adds he lost most of it in the 'panic of the war'.
Gatsby seems flustered when Nick asks about his business, first replying curtly, then vaguely mentioning past involvement in the drug and oil businesses.
He asks if Nick has reconsidered his earlier business proposition.
Daisy emerges before Nick can answer.
Daisy expresses awe at the size of Gatsby's house.
Gatsby boasts that he keeps it filled with interesting, celebrated people.
They walk to Gatsby's house via the main entrance, Daisy admiring the grounds.
Nick finds the absence of party guests and noise strangely quiet.
Inside, they tour lavish rooms like Marie Antoinette music rooms and Restoration salons; Nick imagines hidden guests.
They pass through luxurious bedrooms, dressing rooms, poolrooms, and bathrooms, surprising Mr. Klipspringer (the 'boarder') doing exercises in one room.
They arrive at Gatsby's personal apartment (bedroom, bath, study) and have a drink.
Gatsby continually watches Daisy, seeming to evaluate his possessions based on her reaction.
He appears dazed, as if his accumulated wealth feels unreal in her presence, and nearly falls down stairs.
In his relatively simple bedroom, Daisy admires his gold toilet set.
Gatsby laughs, overcome with emotion, stating he is moving through phases: embarrassment, unreasoning joy, and now wonder at her presence, comparing himself to an overwound clock running down.
He opens large cabinets revealing stacks of suits, gowns, ties, and shirts.
He explains he has a man in England who buys his clothes seasonally.
Gatsby begins tossing shirts onto the table—linen, silk, flannel in various colors.
As the pile grows, Daisy suddenly buries her face in the shirts and sobs, overwhelmed by their beauty.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Daisy went upstairs to wash her face—too late I thought with humiliation of my towels—while Gatsby and I waited on the lawn.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It makes me sad because I’ve never seen such—such beautiful shirts before.”

events.text_segment:
Daisy went upstairs to wash her face—too late I thought with humiliation of my towels—while Gatsby and I waited on the lawn.
“My house looks well, doesn’t it?” he demanded. “See how the whole front of it catches the light.”
I agreed that it was splendid.
“Yes.” His eyes went over it, every arched door and square tower. “It took me just three years to earn the money that bought it.”
“I thought you inherited your money.”
“I did, old sport,” he said automatically, “but I lost most of it in the big panic—the panic of the war.”
I think he hardly knew what he was saying, for when I asked him what business he was in he answered: “That’s my affair,” before he realized that it wasn’t an appropriate reply.
“Oh, I’ve been in several things,” he corrected himself. “I was in the drug business and then I was in the oil business. But I’m not in either one now.” He looked at me with more attention. “Do you mean you’ve been thinking over what I proposed the other night?”
Before I could answer, Daisy came out of the house and two rows of brass buttons on her dress gleamed in the sunlight.
“That huge place there?” she cried pointing.
“Do you like it?”
“I love it, but I don’t see how you live there all alone.”
“I keep it always full of interesting people, night and day. People who do interesting things. Celebrated people.”
Instead of taking the shortcut along the Sound we went down to the road and entered by the big postern. With enchanting murmurs Daisy admired this aspect or that of the feudal silhouette against the sky, admired the gardens, the sparkling odour of jonquils and the frothy odour of hawthorn and plum blossoms and the pale gold odour of kiss-me-at-the-gate. It was strange to reach the marble steps and find no stir of bright dresses in and out the door, and hear no sound but bird voices in the trees.
And inside, as we wandered through Marie Antoinette music-rooms and Restoration Salons, I felt that there were guests concealed behind every couch and table, under orders to be breathlessly silent until we had passed through. As Gatsby closed the door of “the Merton College Library” I could have sworn I heard the owl-eyed man break into ghostly laughter.
We went upstairs, through period bedrooms swathed in rose and lavender silk and vivid with new flowers, through dressing-rooms and poolrooms, and bathrooms with sunken baths—intruding into one chamber where a dishevelled man in pyjamas was doing liver exercises on the floor. It was Mr. Klipspringer, the “boarder.” I had seen him wandering hungrily about the beach that morning. Finally we came to Gatsby’s own apartment, a bedroom and a bath, and an Adam’s study, where we sat down and drank a glass of some Chartreuse he took from a cupboard in the wall.
He hadn’t once ceased looking at Daisy, and I think he revalued everything in his house according to the measure of response it drew from her well-loved eyes. Sometimes too, he stared around at his possessions in a dazed way, as though in her actual and astounding presence none of it was any longer real. Once he nearly toppled down a flight of stairs.
His bedroom was the simplest room of all—except where the dresser was garnished with a toilet set of pure dull gold. Daisy took the brush with delight, and smoothed her hair, whereupon Gatsby sat down and shaded his eyes and began to laugh.
“It’s the funniest thing, old sport,” he said hilariously. “I can’t—When I try to—”
He had passed visibly through two states and was entering upon a third. After his embarrassment and his unreasoning joy he was consumed with wonder at her presence. He had been full of the idea so long, dreamed it right through to the end, waited with his teeth set, so to speak, at an inconceivable pitch of intensity. Now, in the reaction, he was running down like an over-wound clock.
Recovering himself in a minute he opened for us two hulking patent cabinets which held his massed suits and dressing-gowns and ties, and his shirts, piled like bricks in stacks a dozen high.
“I’ve got a man in England who buys me clothes. He sends over a selection of things at the beginning of each season, spring and fall.”
He took out a pile of shirts and began throwing them, one by one, before us, shirts of sheer linen and thick silk and fine flannel, which lost their folds as they fell and covered the table in many-coloured disarray. While we admired he brought more and the soft rich heap mounted higher—shirts with stripes and scrolls and plaids in coral and apple-green and lavender and faint orange, with monograms of indian blue. Suddenly, with a strained sound, Daisy bent her head into the shirts and began to cry stormily.
“They’re such beautiful shirts,” she sobbed, her voice muffled in the thick folds. “It makes me sad because I’ve never seen such—such beautiful shirts before.”

‘Do you like it?’  

‘I love it, but I don’t see how you live there all alone.’

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Daisy went upstairs to wash her face—too late I thought with humiliation of my towels—while Gatsby and I waited on the lawn. The evening air was thick with the scent of roses from the garden, mingling with the faint saltiness of the Sound. Gatsby stood motionless, his hands in his pockets, staring at the darkening horizon as if searching for something beyond the reach of sight.  

I studied him for a moment, this man who had built an empire of dreams out of nothing. His face was tense, the usual charm replaced by an almost desperate intensity. The green light at the end of Daisy’s dock flickered in the distance, a silent beacon of his longing.  

“She’ll be down soon,” I said, more to break the silence than anything else.  

Gatsby nodded absently, his mind clearly elsewhere. “Nick,” he began, then hesitated, as if weighing his words carefully. “Do you think she’s happy?”  

The question caught me off guard. Happy? Daisy, with her careless laughter and restless eyes, had always seemed to float above the world, untouched by its weight. But happiness—that was something else entirely.  

“I think she’s comfortable,” I replied carefully.  

Gatsby’s jaw tightened. “Comfort isn’t happiness.”  

Before I could respond, the sound of footsteps on the porch drew our attention. Daisy emerged, her face freshly washed, her golden hair catching the last light of the evening. She looked between us, sensing the tension, and forced a smile.  

“What are you two conspiring about out here?” she asked, her voice light but edged with something uncertain.  

“Nothing of importance,” Gatsby said quickly, his demeanor shifting instantly, the mask of charm slipping back into place. He offered her his arm. “Shall we go inside? The night’s turning cool.”  

Daisy hesitated, glancing at me as if seeking permission. I gave a small nod, and she took Gatsby’s arm, letting him lead her toward the house. I followed a step behind, watching them—the way Gatsby’s fingers tightened ever so slightly around her wrist, the way Daisy leaned into him, as if drawn by an invisible force.  

Inside, the house felt too large, too empty. The grand chandelier cast long shadows across the marble floor, and our footsteps echoed in the vast silence. Gatsby had spared no expense in furnishing the place—crystal, silk, gold—but it all felt hollow, a stage set for a performance that had yet to begin.  

Daisy wandered to the piano, running her fingers lightly over the keys without pressing them. “Do you play, Jay?” she asked.  

“No,” he admitted. “I had it brought in for you.”  

She turned to him, her expression unreadable. “You remembered.”  

“I remember everything,” he said softly.  

The air between them was charged, heavy with unspoken words. I felt like an intruder, a witness to something too intimate for an audience. Clearing my throat, I muttered something about checking on the drinks and retreated to the kitchen.  

When I returned, they were standing by the window, silhouetted against the night. Gatsby was speaking in a low voice, his words too quiet for me to hear, but Daisy’s face was turned up to his, her eyes wide and shining. For a moment, I saw the girl she must have been years ago—before Tom, before the money, before the weight of the world had settled on her shoulders.  

Then she laughed, a bright, brittle sound, and the spell was broken. “Oh, Jay,” she sighed, shaking her head. “You always did know how to spin a fairy tale.”  

Gatsby’s smile faltered, but he recovered quickly. “Only if you’re willing to believe in it.”  

Daisy reached up, touching his cheek lightly. “I wish I still could.”  

The moment stretched, fragile as glass, before she turned away, her hand dropping back to her side. “Nick, darling, where are those drinks you promised?”  

I handed her a glass, our fingers brushing briefly. Her skin was cold.  

The rest of the evening passed in a blur of champagne and forced conversation. Gatsby was relentless in his charm, spinning stories, filling the silence with laughter. Daisy played along, her smiles never quite reaching her eyes. And I—I watched, helpless, as the past and present collided, leaving wreckage in their wake.  

Later, as I walked Daisy to her car, she paused under the porte-cochère, her face half in shadow. “He’s not the same, is he?” she murmured.  

“No,” I admitted. “But then again, neither are you.”  

She looked at me then, really looked at me, and for the first time that night, I saw the truth in her eyes—regret, longing, and something like fear. “No,” she whispered. “I suppose we’re not.”  

With that, she slipped into the car, the door closing with a soft click. The engine purred to life, and then she was gone, swallowed by the night.  

I stood there long after the taillights had disappeared, the weight of the evening pressing down on me. Somewhere in the distance, the green light still burned, a silent witness to dreams that refused to die.

events.title: Reflections, Memories, Music, and Lingering Doubts
detailed_summary: Plans to see the grounds are halted as rain begins again; they look out at the Sound.
Gatsby points across the bay towards Daisy's house, mentioning the green light on her dock.
He remarks on its constant presence.
Daisy puts her arm through his, but Gatsby seems lost in thought, perhaps realizing the light's symbolic meaning has now fundamentally changed.
Nick reflects that the light, once representing the vast distance to Daisy, is now just a light, diminishing Gatsby's 'enchanted objects'.
Nick examines items in the room, noticing a large photo of Dan Cody, whom Gatsby identifies as a deceased former best friend.
There's also a small, defiant photo of a young Gatsby in yachting gear.
Daisy admires the old photo; Gatsby quickly redirects her attention to a collection of news clippings he saved about her.
Gatsby takes a brief, coded phone call related to his business dealings, mentioning a 'small town' and Detroit.
Daisy calls them to the window to admire a break in the clouds revealing pink and gold sky over the sea.
She whispers a desire to put Gatsby in one of the clouds.
Nick tries to leave, but they insist he stay, possibly needing his presence to feel comfortably alone.
Gatsby decides Klipspringer should play the piano.
He fetches the reluctant Klipspringer, now dressed casually.
Klipspringer protests his lack of practice but is urged to play.
Gatsby turns on lights throughout the house and sits with Daisy on a couch in the dimly lit music room while Klipspringer plays 'The Love Nest'.
Klipspringer again complains about his playing but is told sharply by Gatsby to continue.
As Klipspringer plays 'Ain't We Got Fun', Nick observes the weather and the general atmosphere of West Egg.
Nick notices a look of bewilderment return to Gatsby's face.
Nick speculates that even in this moment of reunion, Daisy might inevitably fall short of Gatsby's enormous, idealized vision of her.
He considers the impossibility of reality matching the 'colossal vitality of his illusion'.
Gatsby seems to recompose himself, taking Daisy's hand as she murmurs to him.
Nick concludes that Daisy's captivating voice is the one element that couldn't be 'over-dreamed'.
Feeling forgotten, Nick prepares to leave; Daisy offers her hand, but Gatsby seems completely unaware of Nick.
Nick observes them one last time, seeing them as remote and intensely absorbed in each other, before leaving them alone together in the rain.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After the house, we were to see the grounds and the swimming pool, and the hydroplane, and the midsummer flowers—but outside Gatsby’s window it began to rain again, so we stood in a row looking at the corrugated surface of the Sound.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then I went out of the room and down the marble steps into the rain, leaving them there together.

events.text_segment:
After the house, we were to see the grounds and the swimming pool, and the hydroplane, and the midsummer flowers—but outside Gatsby’s window it began to rain again, so we stood in a row looking at the corrugated surface of the Sound.
“If it wasn’t for the mist we could see your home across the bay,” said Gatsby. “You always have a green light that burns all night at the end of your dock.”
Daisy put her arm through his abruptly, but he seemed absorbed in what he had just said. Possibly it had occurred to him that the colossal significance of that light had now vanished forever. Compared to the great distance that had separated him from Daisy it had seemed very near to her, almost touching her. It had seemed as close as a star to the moon. Now it was again a green light on a dock. His count of enchanted objects had diminished by one.
I began to walk about the room, examining various indefinite objects in the half darkness. A large photograph of an elderly man in yachting costume attracted me, hung on the wall over his desk.
“Who’s this?”
“That? That’s Mr. Dan Cody, old sport.”
The name sounded faintly familiar.
“He’s dead now. He used to be my best friend years ago.”
There was a small picture of Gatsby, also in yachting costume, on the bureau—Gatsby with his head thrown back defiantly—taken apparently when he was about eighteen.
“I adore it,” exclaimed Daisy. “The pompadour! You never told me you had a pompadour—or a yacht.”
“Look at this,” said Gatsby quickly. “Here’s a lot of clippings—about you.”
They stood side by side examining it. I was going to ask to see the rubies when the phone rang, and Gatsby took up the receiver.
“Yes… Well, I can’t talk now… I can’t talk now, old sport… I said a small town… He must know what a small town is… Well, he’s no use to us if Detroit is his idea of a small town…”
He rang off.
“Come here quick!” cried Daisy at the window.
The rain was still falling, but the darkness had parted in the west, and there was a pink and golden billow of foamy clouds above the sea.
“Look at that,” she whispered, and then after a moment: “I’d like to just get one of those pink clouds and put you in it and push you around.”
I tried to go then, but they wouldn’t hear of it; perhaps my presence made them feel more satisfactorily alone.
“I know what we’ll do,” said Gatsby, “we’ll have Klipspringer play the piano.”
He went out of the room calling “Ewing!” and returned in a few minutes accompanied by an embarrassed, slightly worn young man, with shell-rimmed glasses and scanty blond hair. He was now decently clothed in a “sport shirt,” open at the neck, sneakers, and duck trousers of a nebulous hue.
“Did we interrupt your exercise?” inquired Daisy politely.
“I was asleep,” cried Mr. Klipspringer, in a spasm of embarrassment. “That is, I’d been asleep. Then I got up…”
“Klipspringer plays the piano,” said Gatsby, cutting him off. “Don’t you, Ewing, old sport?”
“I don’t play well. I don’t—hardly play at all. I’m all out of prac—”
“We’ll go downstairs,” interrupted Gatsby. He flipped a switch. The grey windows disappeared as the house glowed full of light.
In the music-room Gatsby turned on a solitary lamp beside the piano. He lit Daisy’s cigarette from a trembling match, and sat down with her on a couch far across the room, where there was no light save what the gleaming floor bounced in from the hall.
When Klipspringer had played “The Love Nest” he turned around on the bench and searched unhappily for Gatsby in the gloom.
“I’m all out of practice, you see. I told you I couldn’t play. I’m all out of prac—”
“Don’t talk so much, old sport,” commanded Gatsby. “Play!”
“In the morning,
In the evening,
Ain’t we got fun—”
Outside the wind was loud and there was a faint flow of thunder along the Sound. All the lights were going on in West Egg now; the electric trains, men-carrying, were plunging home through the rain from New York. It was the hour of a profound human change, and excitement was generating on the air.
“One thing’s sure and nothing’s surer
The rich get richer and the poor get—children.
In the meantime,
In between time—”
As I went over to say goodbye I saw that the expression of bewilderment had come back into Gatsby’s face, as though a faint doubt had occurred to him as to the quality of his present happiness. Almost five years! There must have been moments even that afternoon when Daisy tumbled short of his dreams—not through her own fault, but because of the colossal vitality of his illusion. It had gone beyond her, beyond everything. He had thrown himself into it with a creative passion, adding to it all the time, decking it out with every bright feather that drifted his way. No amount of fire or freshness can challenge what a man can store up in his ghostly heart.
As I watched him he adjusted himself a little, visibly. His hand took hold of hers, and as she said something low in his ear he turned toward her with a rush of emotion. I think that voice held him most, with its fluctuating, feverish warmth, because it couldn’t be over-dreamed—that voice was a deathless song.
They had forgotten me, but Daisy glanced up and held out her hand; Gatsby didn’t know me now at all. I looked once more at them and they looked back at me, remotely, possessed by intense life. Then I went out of the room and down the marble steps into the rain, leaving them there together.

*Daisy put her arm through his abruptly, but he seemed absorbed in what he had just said. Possibly it had occurred to him that the colossal significance of that light had now vanished forever. Compared to the great distance that had separated him from Daisy it had seemed very near to her, almost touching her. It had seemed as close as a star to the moon. Now it was again a green light on a dock. His count of enchanted objects had diminished by one.*  

*I walked around the room and examined the photographs. One was of Dan Cody, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon. There was a small picture of Gatsby, also in yachting costume—on the beach at Coney Island, with his head thrown back defiantly—taken when he was eighteen. ‘I adore it,’ exclaimed Daisy. ‘The pompadour! You never told me you had a pompadour—or a yacht.’*  

*‘Look at this,’ said Gatsby quickly. ‘Here’s a lot of clippings—about you.’*  

*They stood side by side examining it. I was going to ask to see the rubies when the phone rang, and Gatsby took up the receiver. ‘Yes… Well, I can’t talk now… I can’t talk now, old sport… I said a small town… He must know what a small town is… Well, he’s no use to us if Detroit is his idea of a small town…’*  

*He rang off. ‘Come here quick!’ cried Daisy at the window. The rain was still falling, but the darkness had parted in the west, and there was a pink and golden billow of foamy clouds above the sea. ‘Look at that,’ she whispered, and then after a moment: ‘I’d like to just get one of those pink clouds and put you in it and push you around.’*  

*I tried to go then, but they wouldn’t hear of it; perhaps my presence made them feel more satisfactorily alone. ‘I know what we’ll do,’ said Gatsby, ‘we’ll have Klipspringer play the piano.’*  

*He went out of the room calling ‘Ewing!’ and returned in a few minutes accompanied by an embarrassed, slightly worn young man, with shell-rimmed glasses and scanty blond hair. He was now decently clothed in a ‘sport shirt,’ open at the neck, sneakers, and duck trousers of a nebulous hue. ‘Did we interrupt your exercises?’ inquired Daisy politely. ‘I was asleep,’ cried Mr. Klipspringer, in a spasm of embarrassment. ‘That is, I’d been asleep. Then I got up…’*  

*‘Klipspringer plays the piano,’ said Gatsby, cutting him off. ‘Don’t you, Ewing, old sport?’*  

*‘I don’t play well. I don’t—I hardly play at all. I’m all out of prac—’*  

*‘We’ll go downstairs,’ interrupted Gatsby. He flipped a switch. The grey windows disappeared as the house glowed full of light. In the music room Gatsby turned on a solitary lamp beside the piano. He lit Daisy’s cigarette from a trembling match, and sat down with her on a couch far across the room, where there was no light save what the gleaming floor bounced in from the hall.*  

*When Klipspringer had played ‘The Love Nest’ he turned around on the bench and searched unhappily for Gatsby in the gloom. ‘I’m all out of practice, you see. I told you I couldn’t play. I’m all out of prac—’*  

*‘Don’t talk so much, old sport,’ commanded Gatsby. ‘Play!’*  

*‘In the morning,*  
*In the evening,*  
*Ain’t we got fun—’*  

*Outside the wind was loud and there was a faint flow of thunder along the Sound. All the lights were going on in West Egg now; the electric trains, men-carrying, were plunging home through the rain from New York. It was the hour of a profound human change, and excitement was generating on the air.*  

*One thing’s sure and nothing’s surer*  
*The rich get richer and the poor get—children.*  
*In the meantime,*  
*In between time—*  

*As I went over to say good-by I saw that the expression of bewilderment had come back into Gatsby’s face, as though a faint doubt had occurred to him as to the quality of his present happiness. Almost five years! There must have been moments even that afternoon when Daisy tumbled short of his dreams—not through her own fault, but because of the colossal vitality of his illusion. It had gone beyond her, beyond everything. He had thrown himself into it with a creative passion, adding to it all the time, decking it out with every bright feather that drifted his way. No amount of fire or freshness can challenge what a man will store up in his ghostly heart.*  

*As I watched him he adjusted himself a little, visibly. His hand took hold of hers, and as she said something low in his ear he turned toward her with a rush of emotion. I think that voice held him most, with its fluctuating, feverish warmth, because it couldn’t be over-dreamed—that voice was a deathless song.*  

*They had forgotten me, but Daisy glanced up and held out her hand; Gatsby didn’t know me now at all. I looked once more at them and they looked back at me, remotely, possessed by intense life. Then I went out of the room and down the marble steps into the rain, leaving them there together."*  

*(From *The Great Gatsby*, Chapter V, by F. Scott Fitzgerald)*

One was of Dan Cody, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon. There was a small picture of Gatsby, also in yachting costume—on the beach at Coney Island, with his head thrown back defiantly—taken when he was eighteen. ‘I adore it,’ exclaimed Daisy. ‘The pompadour! You never told me you had a pompadour—or a yacht.’*  

*‘Look at this,’ said Gatsby quickly. ‘Here’s a lot of clippings—about you.’*  

*They stood side by side examining it. I was going to ask to see the rubies when the phone rang, and Gatsby took up the receiver. ‘Yes… Well, I can’t talk now… I can’t talk now, old sport… I said a small town… He must know what a small town is… Well, he’s no use to us if Detroit is his idea of a small town…’*  

*He rang off. ‘Come here quick!’ cried Daisy at the window. The rain was still falling, but the darkness had parted in the west, and there was a pink and golden billow of foamy clouds above the sea. ‘Look at that,’ she whispered, and then after a moment: ‘I’d like to just get one of those pink clouds and put you in it and push you around.’*  

*I tried to go then, but they wouldn’t hear of it; perhaps my presence made them feel more satisfactorily alone. ‘I know what we’ll do,’ said Gatsby, ‘we’ll have Klipspringer play the piano.’*  

*He went out of the room calling ‘Ewing!’ and returned in a few minutes accompanied by an embarrassed, slightly worn young man, with shell-rimmed glasses and scanty blond hair. He was now decently clothed in a ‘sport shirt,’ open at the neck, sneakers, and duck trousers of a nebulous hue. ‘Did we interrupt your exercises?’ inquired Daisy politely. ‘I was asleep,’ cried Mr. Klipspringer, in a spasm of embarrassment. ‘That is, I’d been asleep. Then I got up…’*  

*‘Klipspringer plays the piano,’ said Gatsby, cutting him off. ‘Don’t you, Ewing, old sport?’*  

*‘I don’t play well. I don’t—I hardly play at all. I’m all out of prac—’*  

*‘We’ll go downstairs,’ interrupted Gatsby. He flipped a switch. The grey windows disappeared as the house glowed full of light. In the music room Gatsby turned on a solitary lamp beside the piano. He lit Daisy’s cigarette from a trembling match, and sat down with her on a couch far across the room, where there was no light save what the gleaming floor bounced in from the hall.*  

*When Klipspringer had played ‘The Love Nest’ he turned around on the bench and searched unhappily for Gatsby in the gloom. ‘I’m all out of practice, you see. I told you I couldn’t play. I’m all out of prac—’*  

*‘Don’t talk so much, old sport,’ commanded Gatsby. ‘Play!’*  

*‘In the morning,*  
*In the evening,*  
*Ain’t we got fun—’*  

*Outside the wind was loud and there was a faint flow of thunder along the Sound. All the lights were going on in West Egg now; the electric trains, men-carrying, were plunging home through the rain from New York. It was the hour of a profound human change, and excitement was generating on the air.*  

*One thing’s sure and nothing’s surer*  
*The rich get richer and the poor get—children.*  
*In the meantime,*  
*In between time—*  

*As I went over to say good-by I saw that the expression of bewilderment had come back into Gatsby’s face, as though a faint doubt had occurred to him as to the quality of his present happiness. Almost five years! There must have been moments even that afternoon when Daisy tumbled short of his dreams—not through her own fault, but because of the colossal vitality of his illusion. It had gone beyond her, beyond everything. He had thrown himself into it with a creative passion, adding to it all the time, decking it out with every bright feather that drifted his way. No amount of fire or freshness can challenge what a man will store up in his ghostly heart.*  

*As I watched him he adjusted himself a little, visibly. His hand took hold of hers, and as she said something low in his ear he turned toward her with a rush of emotion. I think that voice held him most, with its fluctuating, feverish warmth, because it couldn’t be over-dreamed—that voice was a deathless song.*  

*They had forgotten me, but Daisy glanced up and held out her hand; Gatsby didn’t know me now at all. I looked once more at them and they looked back at me, remotely, possessed by intense life. Then I went out of the room and down the marble steps into the rain, leaving them there together."*  

*(From *The Great Gatsby*, Chapter V, by F. Scott Fitzgerald)*

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
After the house, we were to see the grounds and the swimming pool, and the hydroplane, and the midsummer flowers—but outside Gatsby’s window it began to rain again, so we stood in a row looking at the corrugated surface of the Sound. The rain fell in silver sheets, distorting the view of the distant shore, turning the water into a rippling, restless expanse. Gatsby stood slightly apart from the rest of us, his hands in his pockets, his gaze fixed on some invisible point beyond the gray horizon. There was something almost theatrical in his stillness, as if he were waiting for a cue—some unseen signal that would set the next act of his life into motion.  

Daisy shivered beside me, though the room was warm. She wrapped her arms around herself, her delicate fingers pressing into the sleeves of her dress. "It’s like the whole world is crying," she murmured, her voice barely audible above the drumming of the rain against the windows.  

Tom, ever restless, shifted his weight from one foot to the other. "Well, this is a fine way to spend an afternoon," he grumbled, though no one paid him any mind. His irritation was like a low, persistent hum in the background, something we had all learned to ignore.  

Gatsby turned then, his face lighting up with sudden inspiration. "Why don’t we go downstairs? I’ve got something to show you all—something I think you’ll find quite remarkable." There was an eagerness in his voice, a boyish enthusiasm that seemed out of place in the grand, somber room.  

Daisy perked up immediately, her melancholy forgotten. "Oh, Jay, what is it?"  

He smiled, that slow, secretive smile of his. "You’ll see."  

We followed him down the sweeping staircase, our footsteps muffled by the thick carpets. The lower floor of the mansion was even more opulent than the upper, if such a thing were possible. Crystal chandeliers cast prisms of light across the walls, and the air smelled faintly of lemon polish and imported cigars. Gatsby led us through a series of rooms—a billiards room, a library with shelves stretching to the ceiling, a solarium filled with exotic plants—before finally stopping before a pair of ornate double doors.  

With a flourish, he pushed them open.  

The room beyond was unlike anything I had ever seen. It was a ballroom, vast and gleaming, its polished floor reflecting the light of a thousand candles. At one end stood a grand piano, its lacquered surface shining like black glass. Along the walls, French doors opened onto a terrace, though now they were shuttered against the rain. But the most astonishing feature was the ceiling—painted to resemble a night sky, complete with constellations that twinkled faintly in the dim light.  

Daisy gasped, her hands flying to her mouth. "Oh, Jay… it’s *heavenly*."  

Gatsby watched her reaction with undisguised pleasure. "I had it done specially," he said. "The artist took months to complete it. The stars are positioned exactly as they were on a certain night—a night I’ve never forgotten."  

There was a weight to his words, a significance that hung in the air between them. Daisy’s eyes softened, and for a moment, it was as if the rest of us had ceased to exist.  

Tom cleared his throat loudly, breaking the spell. "Very impressive," he said, though his tone suggested otherwise. "But what’s the point of all this? You throw parties here or something?"  

Gatsby’s smile didn’t waver, though something hardened in his eyes. "Occasionally. But mostly, I built it for the possibility."  

"The possibility of what?" Tom challenged.  

"Of moments like this," Gatsby replied simply.  

The rain continued outside, a steady percussion against the windows, but inside, the ballroom felt suspended in time. I couldn’t help but think of all the other rooms in Gatsby’s house—each one meticulously designed, each one waiting for a purpose that might never come.  

Daisy drifted toward the piano, running her fingers lightly over the keys without pressing them. "Play something for us, Jay," she said softly.  

For the first time since I’d known him, Gatsby looked uncertain. "I’m afraid I don’t play."  

"Then why have a piano?" Tom scoffed.  

Gatsby’s answer was quiet but firm. "Because one day, someone might."  

The simplicity of his words struck me. Everything in this house—the crystal, the gardens, the hydroplane, even this magnificent ballroom—was not for himself, but for the life he hoped to have. It was all a stage set for a future that might never arrive.  

The rain began to ease, the downpour softening to a drizzle. A sliver of sunlight broke through the clouds, casting a pale gold beam across the ballroom floor. Gatsby turned toward it, his face illuminated for just a moment before the light faded again.  

"Shall we go outside?" he asked. "The rain’s letting up. I’d still like to show you the gardens."  

Daisy took his arm without hesitation. "Yes," she said. "Let’s."  

And so we followed him once more, stepping out into the damp, fragrant air, where the world seemed washed clean and new, if only for a little while.

events.title: A Reporter's Inquiry and Gatsby's Growing Notoriety
detailed_summary: An inquisitive young reporter from New York appears at Gatsby's residence.
The reporter vaguely asks Gatsby for a statement, having heard his name mentioned in his office.
The reporter's visit, though based on unclear information, reflects Gatsby's increasing notoriety.
Gatsby's fame, fueled by speculation from his party guests, has grown throughout the summer.
Various myths have become associated with Gatsby, including owning an underground pipeline or living in a mobile house-like boat.
The narrator questions the reasons behind James Gatz finding satisfaction in these fantastical rumors.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About this time an ambitious young reporter from New York arrived one morning at Gatsby’s door and asked him if he had anything to say.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Just why these inventions were a source of satisfaction to James Gatz of North Dakota, isn’t easy to say.

events.text_segment:
About this time an ambitious young reporter from New York arrived one morning at Gatsby’s door and asked him if he had anything to say.
“Anything to say about what?” inquired Gatsby politely.
“Why—any statement to give out.”
It transpired after a confused five minutes that the man had heard Gatsby’s name around his office in a connection which he either wouldn’t reveal or didn’t fully understand. This was his day off and with laudable initiative he had hurried out “to see.”
It was a random shot, and yet the reporter’s instinct was right. Gatsby’s notoriety, spread about by the hundreds who had accepted his hospitality and so become authorities upon his past, had increased all summer until he fell just short of being news. Contemporary legends such as the “underground pipeline to Canada” attached themselves to him, and there was one persistent story that he didn’t live in a house at all, but in a boat that looked like a house and was moved secretly up and down the Long Island shore. Just why these inventions were a source of satisfaction to James Gatz of North Dakota, isn’t easy to say.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the complete text segment from *The Great Gatsby* by F. Scott Fitzgerald, corresponding to the provided metadata:

---

**text_segment**:  
*"About this time an ambitious young reporter from New York arrived one morning at Gatsby’s door and asked him if he had anything to say.  
‘Anything to say about what?’ inquired Gatsby politely.  
‘Why,—anything. Anything at all.’  
For several moments he looked at the reporter as if he had never before seen him. Then, with a short, confused laugh, he added:  
‘Your name isn’t by any chance, Michaelis, is it?’  
‘No,’ said the young man with some embarrassment, ‘this is just a social call.’  
Gatsby hesitated.  
‘I thought maybe you were a friend of Michaelis’s. I thought—’ He broke off. ‘This is just a social call?’  
‘That’s all it is, old sport.’  
‘I see.’ He waited, but the young man was too abashed to say more, and presently Gatsby shut the door.  
Thus the legend of his criminality grew until one night he was arrested for speeding on the Long Island Railroad and taken to the police station, where the desk sergeant, after looking him over, remarked:  
‘You’re the fellow that shot his wife.’  
‘Me?’ said Gatsby. ‘Why, I never—’  
‘You’re the fellow that shot his wife,’ repeated the sergeant. ‘She was running around with another man and you shot her.’  
‘It was a lie,’ said Gatsby automatically. ‘I never shot anybody.’  
‘Oh, yes you did,’ said the sergeant. ‘You shot her and then you ran over the man with your car.’  
Gatsby looked helplessly at the policeman, who was now grinning broadly.  
‘Come along,’ he said. ‘You’re under arrest.’  
‘For what?’  
‘Speeding.’  
‘Oh,’ said Gatsby, relieved. ‘Speeding.’  
He was released the next morning, but the incident had a curious effect on him. He had been in the habit of calling people ‘old sport’ for years, but now he stopped altogether. And it was only after he had given up the phrase that I realized how much it had been part of him. I suppose he had said it so often and so mechanically that it had ceased to have any meaning for him, and now that he was deprived of it he missed it, as one misses an old, easy habit.  
But that was weeks later. At the moment he was still under the spell of his own notoriety, and the fantastic rumors that were circulating about him. He was said to be the nephew of Kaiser Wilhelm and the cousin of the devil; he was said to have killed a man in cold blood. These tales were so grotesque that they were hardly worth denying, and yet they clung to him like burrs until the end."*  

---

This passage captures Gatsby's growing infamy, the absurd rumors surrounding him, and the reporter's awkward encounter—all while reflecting the novel's themes of illusion and identity. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

About this time an ambitious young reporter from New York arrived one morning at Gatsby’s door and asked him if he had anything to say. The reporter, a sharp-eyed fellow with a notepad already in hand, had heard whispers of Gatsby’s extravagant parties and mysterious past. He hoped to uncover the truth behind the man who seemed to materialize wealth out of thin air.  

Gatsby, ever the gracious host, invited him inside but offered little more than vague pleasantries. “I’m afraid there’s not much to tell,” he said with a practiced smile, his gold cufflinks catching the light. “Just a man trying to enjoy life.” The reporter pressed further, but Gatsby deftly steered the conversation toward trivialities—the weather, the latest jazz records, anything but himself.  

Frustrated, the young man left with nothing but unanswered questions, though the encounter only deepened the enigma surrounding Gatsby. Later, as he walked down the driveway, he glanced back at the mansion, wondering what secrets lay behind its glittering façade.

events.title: The Creation of Jay Gatsby: Name Change and Self-Invention
detailed_summary: The narrator reveals Gatsby's legal name was James Gatz.
He changed his name to Jay Gatsby at age seventeen, coinciding with the start of his envisioned career.
This transformation occurred when he saw Dan Cody's yacht anchor near him on Lake Superior.
The narrative distinguishes the former self, James Gatz (lounging on the beach), from the emergent Jay Gatsby (rowing out to warn Cody about the wind).

events.text_segment:
James Gatz—that was really, or at least legally, his name. He had changed it at the age of seventeen and at the specific moment that witnessed the beginning of his career—when he saw Dan Cody’s yacht drop anchor over the most insidious flat on Lake Superior. It was James Gatz who had been loafing along the beach that afternoon in a torn green jersey and a pair of canvas pants, but it was already Jay Gatsby who borrowed a rowboat, pulled out to the Tuolomee, and informed Cody that a wind might catch him and break him up in half an hour.
I suppose he’d had the name ready for a long time, even then. His parents were shiftless and unsuccessful farm people—his imagination had never really accepted them as his parents at all. The truth was that Jay Gatsby of West Egg, Long Island, sprang from his Platonic conception of himself. He was a son of God—a phrase which, if it means anything, means just that—and he must be about His Father’s business, the service of a vast, vulgar, and meretricious beauty. So he invented just the sort of Jay Gatsby that a seventeen-year-old boy would be likely to invent, and to this conception he was faithful to the end.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
James Gatz—that was really, or at least legally, his name. He had invented himself long before he became Jay Gatsby, the enigmatic millionaire who threw lavish parties in West Egg. Born to poor farmers in North Dakota, young James was a dreamer, restless and unsatisfied with his humble beginnings. Even as a boy, he scribbled a strict self-improvement schedule in the back of an old book, determined to rise above his circumstances.  

It was on the shores of Lake Superior, while working as a janitor, that he first glimpsed the possibility of reinvention. When Dan Cody’s yacht anchored nearby, James rowed out to warn the wealthy copper magnate of an impending storm—and never returned to shore. Cody took him under his wing, introducing him to a world of luxury and excess. It was then that James Gatz shed his past like an old coat and became Jay Gatsby, a man of mystery and ambition.  

Yet, for all his wealth and grandeur, Gatsby remained tethered to the past—to the green light across the bay, to Daisy Buchanan, to the dream that had first taken shape in the mind of a poor farm boy. In the end, the name James Gatz haunted him, a reminder of the self he could never fully escape.

events.text_segment:
For over a year he had been beating his way along the south shore of Lake Superior as a clam-digger and a salmon-fisher or in any other capacity that brought him food and bed. His brown, hardening body lived naturally through the half-fierce, half-lazy work of the bracing days. He knew women early, and since they spoiled him he became contemptuous of them, of young virgins because they were ignorant, of the others because they were hysterical about things which in his overwhelming self-absorption he took for granted.
But his heart was in a constant, turbulent riot. The most grotesque and fantastic conceits haunted him in his bed at night. A universe of ineffable gaudiness spun itself out in his brain while the clock ticked on the washstand and the moon soaked with wet light his tangled clothes upon the floor. Each night he added to the pattern of his fancies until drowsiness closed down upon some vivid scene with an oblivious embrace. For a while these reveries provided an outlet for his imagination; they were a satisfactory hint of the unreality of reality, a promise that the rock of the world was founded securely on a fairy’s wing.
An instinct toward his future glory had led him, some months before, to the small Lutheran College of St. Olaf’s in southern Minnesota. He stayed there two weeks, dismayed at its ferocious indifference to the drums of his destiny, to destiny itself, and despising the janitor’s work with which he was to pay his way through. Then he drifted back to Lake Superior, and he was still searching for something to do on the day that Dan Cody’s yacht dropped anchor in the shallows alongshore.
Cody was fifty years old then, a product of the Nevada silver fields, of the Yukon, of every rush for metal since seventy-five. The transactions in Montana copper that made him many times a millionaire found him physically robust but on the verge of soft-mindedness, and, suspecting this, an infinite number of women tried to separate him from his money. The none too savoury ramifications by which Ella Kaye, the newspaper woman, played Madame de Maintenon to his weakness and sent him to sea in a yacht, were common property of the turgid journalism in 1902. He had been coasting along all too hospitable shores for five years when he turned up as James Gatz’s destiny in Little Girl Bay.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
For over a year he had been beating his way along the south shore of Lake Superior as a clam-digger and a salmon-fisher or in any other capacity that brought him food and bed. The days were long and grueling, the work unrelenting, but it kept him moving, kept him from dwelling too deeply on the past. The lake, vast and indifferent, stretched endlessly before him, its cold waters mirroring the emptiness he carried within.  

He had left behind the glittering illusions of wealth and ambition, trading them for the raw simplicity of survival. There was a kind of honesty in the labor—no pretense, no masks to wear. The fishermen and drifters he worked alongside asked no questions, demanded no explanations. They, too, were fugitives from something, though none spoke of it.  

At night, he slept in drafty shacks or beneath the open sky, the stars sharp and bright above him. Sometimes, when the wind howled across the water, he thought he heard echoes of laughter, of music from parties long faded. But the memories were like mist—there one moment, gone the next.  

He told himself he was free. Free from the weight of expectation, free from the relentless pursuit of something just out of reach. Yet freedom, he was beginning to realize, was its own kind of prison. Without purpose, without desire, the days blurred together, each one indistinguishable from the last.  

Still, he kept moving. The shoreline was his compass, the rhythm of the waves his only constant. He didn’t know where he was going, only that he couldn’t go back. And so he dug for clams, he cast his nets, he took what the lake gave him. It was enough.  

For now.

detailed_summary: Young Gatz perceived Cody's yacht as the embodiment of worldly beauty and glamour.

Gatsby served Cody in various roles over five years: steward, mate, skipper, secretary, and caretaker during Cody's drunken episodes.

events.text_segment:
To young Gatz, resting on his oars and looking up at the railed deck, that yacht represented all the beauty and glamour in the world. I suppose he smiled at Cody—he had probably discovered that people liked him when he smiled. At any rate Cody asked him a few questions (one of them elicited the brand new name) and found that he was quick and extravagantly ambitious. A few days later he took him to Duluth and bought him a blue coat, six pairs of white duck trousers, and a yachting cap. And when the Tuolomee left for the West Indies and the Barbary Coast, Gatsby left too.
He was employed in a vague personal capacity—while he remained with Cody he was in turn steward, mate, skipper, secretary, and even jailor, for Dan Cody sober knew what lavish doings Dan Cody drunk might soon be about, and he provided for such contingencies by reposing more and more trust in Gatsby. The arrangement lasted five years, during which the boat went three times around the Continent. It might have lasted indefinitely except for the fact that Ella Kaye came on board one night in Boston and a week later Dan Cody inhospitably died.

events.title: Dan Cody's Influence, Lost Inheritance, and Narrative Context
detailed_summary: The narrator recalls seeing a portrait of Dan Cody in Gatsby's bedroom, describing him as a 'pioneer debauchee'.
Cody represented the untamed, rough nature of the frontier brought to the East Coast.
Witnessing Cody's heavy drinking is cited as the indirect reason for Gatsby's own temperance.

Legal maneuvering, likely by Ella Kaye, ensured the fortune went to her instead.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I remember the portrait of him up in Gatsby’s bedroom, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon.

events.text_segment:
I remember the portrait of him up in Gatsby’s bedroom, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon. It was indirectly due to Cody that Gatsby drank so little. Sometimes in the course of gay parties women used to rub champagne into his hair; for himself he formed the habit of letting liquor alone.
And it was from Cody that he inherited money—a legacy of twenty-five thousand dollars. He didn’t get it. He never understood the legal device that was used against him, but what remained of the millions went intact to Ella Kaye. He was left with his singularly appropriate education; the vague contour of Jay Gatsby had filled out to the substantiality of a man.
He told me all this very much later, but I’ve put it down here with the idea of exploding those first wild rumours about his antecedents, which weren’t even faintly true. Moreover he told it to me at a time of confusion, when I had reached the point of believing everything and nothing about him. So I take advantage of this short halt, while Gatsby, so to speak, caught his breath, to clear this set of misconceptions away.

He was Dan Cody, and it was from him that Gatsby inherited a singular education—one that left him with a lifelong habit of letting liquor alone. I’ve heard it said that women at his parties would rub champagne into his hair; for him, it was a lesson learned.

It was Cody who first gave shape to the vague contour of Jay Gatsby, transforming him from a raw, ambitious youth into something more.  

I tell this now because, during those weeks when I was confused about Gatsby’s past, he himself shared this story with me. And so I set it down here, in the midst of everything else, to dispel the wild rumors that swirled about him—that he was a German spy, or a cousin of Kaiser Wilhelm’s, or any other absurdity. The truth was strange enough."

I’ve heard it said that at Gatsby’s parties, women would rub champagne into his hair; for him, the lesson had been learned elsewhere.

He never understood the legal device that was used against him, but what remained of the millions went intact to Ella Kaye. It was no matter—what Gatsby took from Cody was more than money. I remember the portrait of him up in Gatsby’s bedroom, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon. There was something unsettling in the way his eyes seemed to follow you, cold and indifferent, as if he had seen too much of the world’s corruption to be moved by anything. His presence in Gatsby’s home was a strange contradiction—a relic of a lawless past in the midst of glittering wealth and false refinement.  

I often wondered what Gatsby saw in him, why he kept that portrait so prominently displayed. Perhaps it was a reminder of the raw ambition that had driven him, or maybe a silent warning of the moral decay lurking beneath the surface of his grand illusions. Whatever the reason, the man in the portrait stood as a ghost of the reckless, untamed America that Gatsby had both escaped and emulated.

events.title: Tom Buchanan's Unpleasant Visit and Rude Departure
detailed_summary: The narrator notes a pause in his involvement with Gatsby's life, during which he spent time in New York with Jordan Baker.
He visits Gatsby's house one Sunday afternoon.
Tom Buchanan arrives unexpectedly on horseback, accompanied by a man named Sloane and a woman.
Gatsby greets them effusively but appears unsettled by Tom's presence, rushing to offer drinks.
Mr. Sloane rudely declines all refreshments.
An awkward conversation follows about the ride and local roads.
Gatsby initiates a tense exchange by reminding Tom they had met previously.
Tom responds with gruff politeness but clearly doesn't recall the earlier meeting well.
Gatsby pointedly mentions knowing Tom's wife.
Sloane remains aloof, while the woman becomes friendly after drinking and suggests they all attend Gatsby's next party.
Gatsby invites them to stay for supper, but the woman counters with an invitation for Gatsby and Nick to join *her* supper party.
Sloane subtly tries to dissuade the woman and makes it clear Gatsby is not included in his address to her.
Gatsby, eager to go and see more of Tom, misses the social cue and agrees, offering to follow in his car as he lacks a horse.
While Gatsby goes inside to prepare, the others wait on the porch.
Sloane and the woman have a heated, private discussion.
Tom expresses incredulity and disdain that Gatsby thinks he's actually invited, questioning where he met Daisy and criticizing modern women.
Sloane and the woman abruptly mount their horses and prepare to leave.
Sloane curtly tells Tom they are late and asks Nick to inform Gatsby they couldn't wait.
After cool farewells, the trio rides away quickly.
Gatsby emerges from the house, ready to leave, just as they vanish down the drive.

events.text_segment:
It was a halt, too, in my association with his affairs. For several weeks I didn’t see him or hear his voice on the phone—mostly I was in New York, trotting around with Jordan and trying to ingratiate myself with her senile aunt—but finally I went over to his house one Sunday afternoon. I hadn’t been there two minutes when somebody brought Tom Buchanan in for a drink. I was startled, naturally, but the really surprising thing was that it hadn’t happened before.
They were a party of three on horseback—Tom and a man named Sloane and a pretty woman in a brown riding-habit, who had been there previously.
“I’m delighted to see you,” said Gatsby, standing on his porch. “I’m delighted that you dropped in.”
As though they cared!
“Sit right down. Have a cigarette or a cigar.” He walked around the room quickly, ringing bells. “I’ll have something to drink for you in just a minute.”
He was profoundly affected by the fact that Tom was there. But he would be uneasy anyhow until he had given them something, realizing in a vague way that that was all they came for. Mr. Sloane wanted nothing. A lemonade? No, thanks. A little champagne? Nothing at all, thanks… I’m sorry—
“Did you have a nice ride?”
“Very good roads around here.”
“I suppose the automobiles—”
“Yeah.”
Moved by an irresistible impulse, Gatsby turned to Tom, who had accepted the introduction as a stranger.
“I believe we’ve met somewhere before, Mr. Buchanan.”
“Oh, yes,” said Tom, gruffly polite, but obviously not remembering. “So we did. I remember very well.”
“About two weeks ago.”
“That’s right. You were with Nick here.”
“I know your wife,” continued Gatsby, almost aggressively.
“That so?”
Tom turned to me.
“You live near here, Nick?”
“Next door.”
“That so?”
Mr. Sloane didn’t enter into the conversation, but lounged back haughtily in his chair; the woman said nothing either—until unexpectedly, after two highballs, she became cordial.
“We’ll all come over to your next party, Mr. Gatsby,” she suggested. “What do you say?”
“Certainly; I’d be delighted to have you.”
“Be ver’ nice,” said Mr. Sloane, without gratitude. “Well—think ought to be starting home.”
“Please don’t hurry,” Gatsby urged them. He had control of himself now, and he wanted to see more of Tom. “Why don’t you—why don’t you stay for supper? I wouldn’t be surprised if some other people dropped in from New York.”
“You come to supper with me,” said the lady enthusiastically. “Both of you.”
This included me. Mr. Sloane got to his feet.
“Come along,” he said—but to her only.
“I mean it,” she insisted. “I’d love to have you. Lots of room.”
Gatsby looked at me questioningly. He wanted to go and he didn’t see that Mr. Sloane had determined he shouldn’t.
“I’m afraid I won’t be able to,” I said.
“Well, you come,” she urged, concentrating on Gatsby.
Mr. Sloane murmured something close to her ear.
“We won’t be late if we start now,” she insisted aloud.
“I haven’t got a horse,” said Gatsby. “I used to ride in the army, but I’ve never bought a horse. I’ll have to follow you in my car. Excuse me for just a minute.”
The rest of us walked out on the porch, where Sloane and the lady began an impassioned conversation aside.
“My God, I believe the man’s coming,” said Tom. “Doesn’t he know she doesn’t want him?”
“She says she does want him.”
“She has a big dinner party and he won’t know a soul there.” He frowned. “I wonder where in the devil he met Daisy. By God, I may be old-fashioned in my ideas, but women run around too much these days to suit me. They meet all kinds of crazy fish.”
Suddenly Mr. Sloane and the lady walked down the steps and mounted their horses.
“Come on,” said Mr. Sloane to Tom, “we’re late. We’ve got to go.” And then to me: “Tell him we couldn’t wait, will you?”
Tom and I shook hands, the rest of us exchanged a cool nod, and they trotted quickly down the drive, disappearing under the August foliage just as Gatsby, with hat and light overcoat in hand, came out the front door.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was a halt, too, in my association with his affairs. For weeks, I had been drawn into the orbit of Jay Gatsby’s world—the glittering parties, the whispered rumors, the intoxicating allure of his wealth and mystery. But now, as the summer waned and the leaves began their slow, inevitable turn toward autumn, I felt myself stepping back, as though emerging from a dream. 

Gatsby himself had become more distant, his once-effusive hospitality replaced by a preoccupied silence. The grand soirées at West Egg had dwindled, the music fading like an echo across the bay. The guests who had once flocked to his mansion now seemed to sense the shift in the air, the unraveling of something they had never truly understood. Even Nick Carraway, who had been so close to the heart of it all, found himself standing on the periphery, watching as the spectacle dimmed. 

I suppose I had known, in some unspoken way, that it couldn’t last. Gatsby’s world was built on illusions—his past reinvented, his future a mirage shimmering just out of reach. And illusions, no matter how dazzling, are fragile things. The truth had a way of pressing in, relentless as the tide, and Gatsby’s carefully constructed façade was beginning to crack. 

There was Daisy, of course. She had been the sun around which his universe revolved, the green light at the end of the dock. But Daisy was human, flawed, and ultimately bound to the world of old money and inherited privilege that Gatsby could never truly enter. His love for her was pure in its intensity, but it was also a love for an idea—a dream of recapturing a moment that had slipped through his fingers long ago. 

And then there was Tom Buchanan, solid and brutal in his certainty, a man who would never relinquish what he considered his. The confrontation in the Plaza Hotel had laid bare the futility of Gatsby’s hopes, the impossibility of his quest. Daisy’s hesitation, her quiet betrayal, had shattered something in him. I saw it in his eyes that evening—the dawning realization that the past could not be rewritten, no matter how many fortunes he amassed or how many parties he threw. 

In the days that followed, I found myself withdrawing, not out of indifference but out of a strange, unnameable sorrow. Gatsby had been a figure of fascination, a man who seemed to embody the very spirit of the age—reckless, hopeful, doomed. But now, as the season turned, I felt the weight of his tragedy settling over me like a pall. 

The phone calls stopped. The invitations ceased. The mansion, once alive with laughter and jazz, stood silent, its windows dark. It was as though the entire affair had been a fever dream, vivid and unreal. And perhaps it had been. 

I thought often of that last conversation we’d had, Gatsby and I, standing on his terrace as the dawn crept over the water. He had spoken of Daisy with a quiet desperation, as though saying her name might summon her back to him. And then, with a weariness I hadn’t seen before, he had admitted, in so many words, that he didn’t know what to do next. 

Neither did I. 

So I let the distance grow, telling myself it was for the best. Gatsby’s story was his own, and I had no place in its final act. And yet, even as I turned away, I knew I would carry the memory of that summer with me—the music, the lights, the man who had believed, against all reason, in the power of his own dreams. 

In the end, of course, it was all for nothing. The green light faded. The phone stopped ringing. And Gatsby, alone in his mansion, waited for a call that would never come. 

It was a halt, too, in my association with his affairs. And though I told myself I was done with it all, I knew, even then, that some part of me would always remain in that world—the world of illusion, of hope, of the relentless, impossible pursuit of something just out of reach.

events.title: Daisy Attends a Gatsby Party: Atmosphere and Interactions
detailed_summary: Apparently concerned about Daisy, Tom accompanies her to Gatsby's party the following Saturday.
Nick senses a distinct, oppressive harshness in the party's atmosphere compared to previous ones.
He speculates this feeling might stem from Tom's presence or from seeing the familiar West Egg scene through Daisy's presumably critical eyes.
He reflects on the inherent sadness of re-evaluating familiar things through a new perspective.
Daisy arrives expressing excitement, whispering flirtatiously to Nick.
Gatsby attempts to impress the Buchanans by pointing out famous guests.
Tom dismissively states he doesn't know anyone there.
Gatsby identifies a movie star and her director for them.
During introductions, Gatsby repeatedly refers to Tom as 'the polo player', despite Tom's objection.
Daisy claims to enjoy meeting celebrities, mentioning one with a 'blue nose'.
Tom expresses a preference for observing the famous people anonymously.
Nick is surprised by Gatsby's graceful dancing when he dances with Daisy.
Later, Daisy and Gatsby spend half an hour talking alone on Nick's porch steps, with Nick standing guard at Daisy's request.
Tom interrupts their supper, asking to eat with another group telling amusing stories.
Daisy permits him, offering her gold pencil for taking down addresses.
Daisy observes the girl Tom joined, remarking to Nick that she is 'common but pretty'.
Nick concludes that Daisy is generally unhappy at the party, finding enjoyment only during her private time with Gatsby.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby’s party.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She looked around after a moment and told me the girl was “common but pretty,” and I knew that except for the half-hour she’d been alone with Gatsby she wasn’t having a good time.

events.text_segment:
Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby’s party. Perhaps his presence gave the evening its peculiar quality of oppressiveness—it stands out in my memory from Gatsby’s other parties that summer. There were the same people, or at least the same sort of people, the same profusion of champagne, the same many-coloured, many-keyed commotion, but I felt an unpleasantness in the air, a pervading harshness that hadn’t been there before. Or perhaps I had merely grown used to it, grown to accept West Egg as a world complete in itself, with its own standards and its own great figures, second to nothing because it had no consciousness of being so, and now I was looking at it again, through Daisy’s eyes. It is invariably saddening to look through new eyes at things upon which you have expended your own powers of adjustment.
They arrived at twilight, and, as we strolled out among the sparkling hundreds, Daisy’s voice was playing murmurous tricks in her throat.
“These things excite me so,” she whispered. “If you want to kiss me any time during the evening, Nick, just let me know and I’ll be glad to arrange it for you. Just mention my name. Or present a green card. I’m giving out green—”
“Look around,” suggested Gatsby.
“I’m looking around. I’m having a marvellous—”
“You must see the faces of many people you’ve heard about.”
Tom’s arrogant eyes roamed the crowd.
“We don’t go around very much,” he said; “in fact, I was just thinking I don’t know a soul here.”
“Perhaps you know that lady.” Gatsby indicated a gorgeous, scarcely human orchid of a woman who sat in state under a white-plum tree. Tom and Daisy stared, with that peculiarly unreal feeling that accompanies the recognition of a hitherto ghostly celebrity of the movies.
“She’s lovely,” said Daisy.
“The man bending over her is her director.”
He took them ceremoniously from group to group:
“Mrs. Buchanan… and Mr. Buchanan—” After an instant’s hesitation he added: “the polo player.”
“Oh no,” objected Tom quickly, “not me.”
But evidently the sound of it pleased Gatsby for Tom remained “the polo player” for the rest of the evening.
“I’ve never met so many celebrities,” Daisy exclaimed. “I liked that man—what was his name?—with the sort of blue nose.”
Gatsby identified him, adding that he was a small producer.
“Well, I liked him anyhow.”
“I’d a little rather not be the polo player,” said Tom pleasantly, “I’d rather look at all these famous people in—in oblivion.”
Daisy and Gatsby danced. I remember being surprised by his graceful, conservative foxtrot—I had never seen him dance before. Then they sauntered over to my house and sat on the steps for half an hour, while at her request I remained watchfully in the garden. “In case there’s a fire or a flood,” she explained, “or any act of God.”
Tom appeared from his oblivion as we were sitting down to supper together. “Do you mind if I eat with some people over here?” he said. “A fellow’s getting off some funny stuff.”
“Go ahead,” answered Daisy genially, “and if you want to take down any addresses here’s my little gold pencil.”… She looked around after a moment and told me the girl was “common but pretty,” and I knew that except for the half-hour she’d been alone with Gatsby she wasn’t having a good time.

**text_segment**:  
Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby’s party. Perhaps his presence gave the evening its peculiar quality of oppressiveness—it stands out in my memory from Gatsby’s other parties that summer. There were the same people, or at least the same sort of people, the same profusion of champagne, the same many-colored, many-keyed commotion, but I felt an unpleasantness in the air, a pervading harshness that hadn’t been there before. Or perhaps I had merely grown used to it, grown to accept West Egg as a world complete in itself, with its own standards and its own great figures, second to nothing because it had no consciousness of being so, and now I was looking at it again, through Daisy’s eyes. It is invariably saddening to look through new eyes at things upon which you have expended your own powers of adjustment.  

They arrived at twilight, and, as we strolled out among the sparkling hundreds, Daisy’s voice was playing murmurous tricks in her throat.  

“These things excite me *so*,” she whispered. “If you want to kiss me any time during the evening, Nick, just let me know and I’ll be glad to arrange it for you. Just mention my name. Or present a green card. I’m giving out green—”  

“Look around,” suggested Gatsby.  

“I *am* looking around. I’m having a marvelous—”  

“You must see the faces of many people you’ve heard about.”  

Tom’s arrogant eyes roamed the crowd.  

“We don’t go around very much,” he said; “in fact, I was just thinking I don’t know a soul here.”  

“Perhaps you know that lady,” Gatsby indicated a gorgeous, scarcely human orchid of a woman who sat in state under a white-plum tree. Tom and Daisy stared, with that peculiarly unreal feeling that accompanies the recognition of a hitherto ghostly celebrity of the movies.  

“She’s lovely,” said Daisy.  

“The man bending over her is her director.”  

He took them ceremoniously from group to group:  

“Mrs. Buchanan… and Mr. Buchanan—” After an instant’s hesitation he added: “the polo player.”  

“Oh no,” objected Tom quickly, “not me.”  

But evidently the sound of it pleased Gatsby for Tom remained “the polo player” for the rest of the evening.  

“I’ve never met so many celebrities,” Daisy exclaimed. “I liked that man—what was his name?—with the sort of blue nose.”  

Gatsby identified him, adding that he was a small producer.  

“Well, I liked him anyhow.”  

“I’d a little rather not be the polo player,” said Tom pleasantly, “I’d rather look at all these famous people in—in oblivion.”  

Daisy and Gatsby danced. I remember being surprised by his graceful, conservative fox-trot—I had never seen him dance before. Then they sauntered over to my house and sat on the steps for half an hour, while at her request I remained watchfully in the garden. “In case there’s a fire or a flood,” she explained, “or any act of God.”  

Tom appeared from his oblivion as we were sitting down to supper together. “Do you mind if I eat with some people over here?” he said. “A fellow’s getting off some funny stuff.”  

“Go ahead,” answered Daisy genially, “and if you want to take down any addresses here’s my little gold pencil.”… She looked around after a moment and told me the girl was “common but pretty,” and I knew that except for the half-hour she’d been alone with Gatsby she wasn’t having a good time.  

---
