LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. The sky was overcast, a dull gray that matched the heaviness in my chest. The train ride felt interminable, each passing mile a reminder of the futility of my mission. Gatsby was dead, and the world moved on as if nothing had happened. The newspapers had already moved on to fresher scandals, and the phone calls I’d made to Wolfshiem’s office had gone unanswered. If anyone could tell me more about Gatsby—who he really was, where he came from—it was him.  

I found Wolfshiem in a dimly lit back room of a nondescript restaurant near Times Square. The air was thick with cigar smoke, and the clinking of glasses and low murmurs of conversation made the place feel like a secret meeting ground for men who preferred shadows to sunlight. Wolfshiem himself sat at a corner table, his small, shrewd eyes flickering up at me as I approached. He was a man who had built his fortune on discretion, and his expression gave nothing away.  

“Mr. Carraway,” he said, his voice gravelly. “I was sorry to hear about Jimmy.”  

There was something hollow in the way he said it, as if he were reciting a line he’d rehearsed. I sat down across from him, my hands clenched on the table. “You didn’t come to the funeral,” I said bluntly.  

Wolfshiem’s fingers twitched around his cigar. “Funerals are bad for business, my boy. And besides, Jimmy wouldn’t have wanted a scene.”  

“He would have wanted someone there,” I said, my voice sharper than I intended. “Someone who knew him before all of this.”  

Wolfshiem exhaled a slow stream of smoke, studying me through the haze. “You think you knew him?”  

“I thought I did.”  

He gave a small, humorless laugh. “Jimmy was a man who believed in the green light, Mr. Carraway. The future. The past didn’t matter to him—only what he could become.”  

“But where did he come from?” I pressed. “Who was he before all of this?”  

Wolfshiem leaned back, his expression unreadable. “A boy with nothing. A boy who wanted everything. That’s all you need to know.”  

I felt a surge of frustration. “He deserved more than this. More than being forgotten before he was even buried.”  

For the first time, something flickered in Wolfshiem’s eyes—something like regret, or maybe guilt. “Jimmy made his choices,” he said quietly. “And so did I. The world doesn’t stop for dead men, no matter how bright they burned.”  

I left soon after, the weight of his words settling over me like a shroud. Outside, the city roared on, indifferent. The streets were full of people rushing to their next destination, their faces turned toward their own dreams, their own green lights. And Gatsby—Jay Gatsby, with his grand illusions and his boundless hope—was already fading into the past, just another ghost in a city that had no time for ghosts.  

I walked back to the train station, the sky still heavy with unshed rain. Somewhere, I thought, there must be more to his story. But perhaps it didn’t matter. Perhaps the truth was that Gatsby had always been exactly what he appeared to be: a man who believed in the impossible, even when the world refused to.  

And in the end, that was the tragedy of it all.

events.title: Mr. Gatz's Pride and Gatsby's Boyhood Ambitions
detailed_summary: Nick returns to West Egg amidst darkening skies and drizzle.
He finds Mr. Gatz pacing excitedly, his pride in Gatsby and his possessions growing.
Mr. Gatz eagerly shows Nick a worn photograph of Gatsby's house that Jimmy had sent him, pointing out details.
He recounts Gatsby visiting two years prior and buying him the house he currently lives in.
Mr. Gatz reflects that Gatsby's running away from home was justified by his ambition for a 'big future'.
He emphasizes Gatsby's generosity after achieving success.
Mr. Gatz then reveals an old, ragged copy of 'Hopalong Cassidy' belonging to Gatsby as a boy.
He shows Nick the back flyleaf containing a detailed daily schedule dated September 12, 1906.
The schedule includes time for exercise, study (electricity, elocution, inventions), work, and sports.
Beneath the schedule are 'General Resolves': avoiding wasted time, quitting smoking/chewing, bathing regularly, reading improving material, saving money, and being better to parents.
Mr. Gatz sees the book and its contents as proof of Jimmy's inherent drive to 'get ahead' and improve himself.
He proudly reads the items aloud, expecting Nick to be deeply impressed.

events.text_segment:
When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. After changing my clothes I went next door and found Mr. Gatz walking up and down excitedly in the hall. His pride in his son and in his son’s possessions was continually increasing and now he had something to show me.
“Jimmy sent me this picture.” He took out his wallet with trembling fingers. “Look there.”
It was a photograph of the house, cracked in the corners and dirty with many hands. He pointed out every detail to me eagerly. “Look there!” and then sought admiration from my eyes. He had shown it so often that I think it was more real to him now than the house itself.
“Jimmy sent it to me. I think it’s a very pretty picture. It shows up well.”
“Very well. Had you seen him lately?”
“He come out to see me two years ago and bought me the house I live in now. Of course we was broke up when he run off from home, but I see now there was a reason for it. He knew he had a big future in front of him. And ever since he made a success he was very generous with me.”
He seemed reluctant to put away the picture, held it for another minute, lingeringly, before my eyes. Then he returned the wallet and pulled from his pocket a ragged old copy of a book called Hopalong Cassidy.
“Look here, this is a book he had when he was a boy. It just shows you.”
He opened it at the back cover and turned it around for me to see. On the last flyleaf was printed the word schedule, and the date September 12, 1906. And underneath:
Rise from bed	6:00	a.m.
Dumbell exercise and wall-scaling	6:15⁠–⁠6:30	“
Study electricity, etc.	7:15⁠–⁠8:15	“
Work	8:30⁠–⁠4:30	p.m.
Baseball and sports	4:30⁠–⁠5:00	“
Practise elocution, poise and how to attain it	5:00⁠–⁠6:00	“
Study needed inventions	7:00⁠–⁠9:00	“
General Resolves
No wasting time at Shafters or [a name, indecipherable]
No more smokeing or chewing.
Bath every other day
Read one improving book or magazine per week
Save $5.00 [crossed out] $3.00 per week
Be better to parents
“I came across this book by accident,” said the old man. “It just shows you, don’t it?”
“It just shows you.”
“Jimmy was bound to get ahead. He always had some resolves like this or something. Do you notice what he’s got about improving his mind? He was always great for that. He told me I et like a hog once, and I beat him for it.”
He was reluctant to close the book, reading each item aloud and then looking eagerly at me. I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.

While we admired he brought more and the soft rich heap mounted higher—shirts with stripes and scrolls and plaids in coral and apple-green and lavender and faint orange, with monograms of Indian blue. “They’re such beautiful shirts,” she sobbed, her voice muffled in the thick folds. “It makes me sad because I’ve never seen such—such beautiful shirts before.”

Daisy put her arm through his abruptly, but he seemed absorbed in what he had just said. Possibly it had occurred to him that the colossal significance of that light had now vanished forever. Compared to the great distance that had separated him from Daisy it had seemed very near to her, almost touching her. It had seemed as close as a star to the moon. Now it was again a green light on a dock. His count of enchanted objects had diminished by one.

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
When I left his office, the sky had turned dark, and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. The rain was light but persistent, blurring the edges of the world as if reality itself had softened. The streets glistened under the dim glow of streetlamps, their reflections stretching like ghosts across the pavement. I walked slowly, my mind still tangled in the conversation I’d had with Gatsby earlier that day. His words echoed in my head, full of hope and desperation, a strange mix that left me unsettled.  

The air smelled of wet earth and distant salt from the Sound, a reminder of how close we all were to the water, yet how far apart we remained in every other way. I thought of Daisy, of the way Gatsby’s voice had trembled when he spoke her name, as if it were something sacred. There was something tragic in his devotion, something that made me both admire and pity him.  

By the time I reached my house, the drizzle had thickened into a steady rain. I stood for a moment under the shelter of my porch, watching the droplets bead on the leaves of the hedges. The green seemed unnaturally vivid against the gray sky, like a last defiant burst of life before the gloom swallowed everything.  

Inside, the silence was heavy. I lit a cigarette and stared out the window, half-expecting to see the green light across the bay, though I knew it was too early for Gatsby to be standing there, reaching for something just out of grasp. The rain tapped against the glass, a quiet, rhythmic sound that only deepened my sense of isolation.  

I wondered if Gatsby was out there now, pacing his mansion, rehearsing what he would say to Daisy when they finally met again. Or perhaps he was staring at his collection of shirts, those dazzling, meaningless symbols of the wealth he’d amassed just for her. It was all so extravagant, so futile. And yet, I couldn’t bring myself to dismiss it entirely. There was something undeniably human in his longing, something that made his grand gestures feel less like vanity and more like a plea to be seen, to be loved.  

The rain continued through the night, a steady companion to my thoughts. I knew tomorrow would bring more of Gatsby’s elaborate plans, more of his desperate hope. And I knew, with a sinking certainty, that none of it would end the way he dreamed. But for now, there was only the sound of the rain and the quiet ache of knowing that some dreams, no matter how brightly they burn, are destined to drown in the storm.

events.title: The Sparse Funeral
detailed_summary: Shortly before 3 PM, the Lutheran minister arrives for the funeral.
Nick and Mr. Gatz anxiously watch for other mourners, but none arrive.
As time passes, Mr. Gatz becomes increasingly worried, commenting nervously about the rain.
The minister checks his watch repeatedly; Nick persuades him to wait half an hour longer, but it's futile.
Around 5 PM, a small procession of three vehicles (hearse, limousine with Nick, Gatz, and minister, and station wagon with servants and postman) reaches the cemetery in heavy drizzle.
As they enter the cemetery, Nick hears a car stop and sees someone approaching.
It is the 'owl-eyed man' Nick previously met in Gatsby's library.
Owl Eyes, soaked by the rain, wipes his glasses to watch the burial.
Nick momentarily tries to think of Gatsby but finds him distant, only recalling Daisy's silence.
Someone murmurs a blessing for the dead in the rain, and Owl Eyes says 'Amen'.
After the brief ceremony, the attendees quickly return to the cars.
Owl Eyes speaks to Nick at the gate, expressing surprise that no one else came, remarking how hundreds used to attend Gatsby's parties.
He wipes his glasses again and calls Gatsby 'The poor son-of-a-bitch'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he said.

events.text_segment:
A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars. So did Gatsby’s father. And as the time passed and the servants came in and stood waiting in the hall, his eyes began to blink anxiously, and he spoke of the rain in a worried, uncertain way. The minister glanced several times at his watch, so I took him aside and asked him to wait for half an hour. But it wasn’t any use. Nobody came.
About five o’clock our procession of three cars reached the cemetery and stopped in a thick drizzle beside the gate—first a motor hearse, horribly black and wet, then Mr. Gatz and the minister and me in the limousine, and a little later four or five servants and the postman from West Egg, in Gatsby’s station wagon, all wet to the skin. As we started through the gate into the cemetery I heard a car stop and then the sound of someone splashing after us over the soggy ground. I looked around. It was the man with owl-eyed glasses whom I had found marvelling over Gatsby’s books in the library one night three months before.
I’d never seen him since then. I don’t know how he knew about the funeral, or even his name. The rain poured down his thick glasses, and he took them off and wiped them to see the protecting canvas unrolled from Gatsby’s grave.
I tried to think about Gatsby then for a moment, but he was already too far away, and I could only remember, without resentment, that Daisy hadn’t sent a message or a flower. Dimly I heard someone murmur “Blessed are the dead that the rain falls on,” and then the owl-eyed man said “Amen to that,” in a brave voice.
We straggled down quickly through the rain to the cars. Owl-eyes spoke to me by the gate.
“I couldn’t get to the house,” he remarked.
“Neither could anybody else.”
“Go on!” He started. “Why, my God! they used to go there by the hundreds.”
He took off his glasses and wiped them again, outside and in.
“The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he said.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars. The oppressive heat of the afternoon pressed against the windows, distorting the view of the driveway where Gatsby’s grand yellow car still stood, a silent witness to the tragedy that had unfolded. The minister, a gaunt man with a solemn face, moved with quiet efficiency, as though accustomed to the weight of grief that filled the room.  

I wondered if anyone else would come. The Buchanans had vanished, retreating behind the walls of their East Egg mansion, untouched by the consequences of their carelessness. Tom, no doubt, had already spun some self-serving tale to absolve himself, while Daisy, fragile as ever, would let the world believe whatever suited her. Even Meyer Wolfsheim, Gatsby’s shadowy associate, had sent only a curt telegram expressing regret—though whether for Gatsby’s death or the inconvenience it caused him, I couldn’t say.  

Only a handful of us remained—Nick, the minister, a few servants, and myself—standing in that echoing West Egg mansion that had once thrummed with music and laughter. The emptiness was unbearable. I thought of Gatsby’s extravagant parties, the crowds who had drunk his champagne and danced on his lawn, now nowhere to be found. Where were they now, those fair-weather friends who had clamored for his hospitality?  

The minister cleared his throat, signaling the start of the service. His words were measured, impersonal, as if he were reciting a script for a man he had never known. And why should he have known him? Gatsby had been a mystery even to those who thought themselves closest to him.  

As the brief ceremony concluded, I glanced once more out the window. The driveway remained empty. No mourners, no flowers, no final tribute—just the relentless sun beating down on a life that had burned too brightly, and too briefly, before vanishing into the indifferent air.

events.title: Reflections on East vs. West and Decision to Leave
detailed_summary: Nick recalls vivid memories of returning home to the Midwest from school during Christmas.
He describes the atmosphere at Chicago's Union Station, the goodbyes, and the train journey into the snowy landscape.
He reflects on the feeling of connection to his homeland experienced during those trips.
Nick defines his Midwest not by landscapes but by these youthful returns and the cozy familiarity of home.
He realizes the story he's told is fundamentally about Westerners (himself, Gatsby, Tom, Daisy, Jordan) who were ill-suited to Eastern life.
Even at its most exciting, Nick found the East possessed a 'quality of distortion'.
He envisions West Egg as a grotesque night scene, comparing it to an El Greco painting, symbolizing moral decay and indifference.
After Gatsby's death, the East feels irredeemably haunted and distorted to Nick.
As autumn sets in, he decides to leave the East and return home to the Midwest.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line I decided to come back home.

events.text_segment:
One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. Those who went farther than Chicago would gather in the old dim Union Station at six o’clock of a December evening, with a few Chicago friends, already caught up into their own holiday gaieties, to bid them a hasty goodbye. I remember the fur coats of the girls returning from Miss This-or-That’s and the chatter of frozen breath and the hands waving overhead as we caught sight of old acquaintances, and the matchings of invitations: “Are you going to the Ordways’? the Herseys’? the Schultzes’?” and the long green tickets clasped tight in our gloved hands. And last the murky yellow cars of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul railroad looking cheerful as Christmas itself on the tracks beside the gate.
When we pulled out into the winter night and the real snow, our snow, began to stretch out beside us and twinkle against the windows, and the dim lights of small Wisconsin stations moved by, a sharp wild brace came suddenly into the air. We drew in deep breaths of it as we walked back from dinner through the cold vestibules, unutterably aware of our identity with this country for one strange hour, before we melted indistinguishably into it again.
That’s my Middle West—not the wheat or the prairies or the lost Swede towns, but the thrilling returning trains of my youth, and the street lamps and sleigh bells in the frosty dark and the shadows of holly wreaths thrown by lighted windows on the snow. I am part of that, a little solemn with the feel of those long winters, a little complacent from growing up in the Carraway house in a city where dwellings are still called through decades by a family’s name. I see now that this has been a story of the West, after all—Tom and Gatsby, Daisy and Jordan and I, were all Westerners, and perhaps we possessed some deficiency in common which made us subtly unadaptable to Eastern life.
Even when the East excited me most, even when I was most keenly aware of its superiority to the bored, sprawling, swollen towns beyond the Ohio, with their interminable inquisitions which spared only the children and the very old—even then it had always for me a quality of distortion. West Egg, especially, still figures in my more fantastic dreams. I see it as a night scene by El Greco: a hundred houses, at once conventional and grotesque, crouching under a sullen, overhanging sky and a lustreless moon. In the foreground four solemn men in dress suits are walking along the sidewalk with a stretcher on which lies a drunken woman in a white evening dress. Her hand, which dangles over the side, sparkles cold with jewels. Gravely the men turn in at a house—the wrong house. But no one knows the woman’s name, and no one cares.
After Gatsby’s death the East was haunted for me like that, distorted beyond my eyes’ power of correction. So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line I decided to come back home.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**:  
*"One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. Those who went farther than Chicago would gather in the old dim Union Station at six o’clock of a December evening, with a few Chicago friends, already caught up into their own holiday gayeties, to bid them a hasty good-by. I remember the fur coats of the girls returning from Miss This-or-That’s and the chatter of frozen breath and the hands waving overhead as we caught sight of old acquaintances, and the matchings of invitations: ‘Are you going to the Ordways’? the Herseys’? the Schultzes’?’ and the long green tickets clasped tight in our gloved hands. And last the murky yellow cars of the Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul railroad looking cheerful as Christmas itself on the tracks beside the gate.*  

*When we pulled out into the winter night and the real snow, our snow, began to stretch out beside us and twinkle against the windows, and the dim lights of small Wisconsin stations moved by, a sharp wild brace came suddenly into the air. We drew in deep breaths of it as we walked back from dinner through the cold vestibules, unutterably aware of our identity with this country for one strange hour, before we melted indistinguishably into it again.*  

*That’s my Middle West—not the wheat or the prairies or the lost Swede towns, but the thrilling returning trains of my youth, and the street lamps and sleigh bells in the frosty dark and the shadows of holly wreaths thrown by lighted windows on the snow. I am part of that, a little solemn with the feel of those long winters, a little complacent from growing up in the Carraway house in a city where dwellings are still called through decades by a family’s name. I see now that this has been a story of the West, after all—Tom and Gatsby, Daisy and Jordan and I, were all Westerners, and perhaps we possessed some deficiency in common which made us subtly unadaptable to Eastern life.*  

*Even when the East excited me most, even when I was most keenly aware of its superiority to the bored, sprawling, swollen towns beyond the Ohio, with their interminable inquisitions which spared only the children and the very old—even then it had always for me a quality of distortion. West Egg, especially, still figures in my more fantastic dreams. I see it as a night scene by El Greco: a hundred houses, at once conventional and grotesque, crouching under a sullen, overhanging sky and a lustreless moon. In the foreground four solemn men in dress suits are walking along the sidewalk with a stretcher on which lies a drunken woman in a white evening dress. Her hand, which dangles over the side, sparkles cold with jewels. The men turn in at a house—the wrong house. But no one knows the woman’s name, and no one cares.*  

*After Gatsby’s death the East was haunted for me like that, distorted beyond my eyes’ power of correction. So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line I decided to come back home."*  

*(The Great Gatsby, Chapter IX)*

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. There was something magical about those journeys—the crisp winter air, the snow-dusted landscapes rushing past the train window, and the anticipation of home. The farther west the train carried me, the more the world seemed to open up, shedding the constraints of the East with its rigid social codes and suffocating expectations. Out here, the sky stretched endlessly, and the land felt untamed, full of possibility.  

I remember one particular December, the train pulling into St. Paul, where the platform was crowded with families reuniting, their breath visible in the cold air. The scent of pine and burning coal filled the station, mingling with the laughter of children and the greetings of old friends. I stood there, gripping my suitcase, scanning the crowd for familiar faces. My parents were there, of course, but it was the sight of my younger sister, her cheeks flushed from the cold, running toward me with unrestrained joy, that made my heart swell.  

Christmas in the West was different—simpler, warmer. There were no grand parties like those I had heard about in New York, no whispered gossip about fortunes and reputations. Instead, there were evenings by the fire, my father reading aloud from Dickens, my mother humming carols as she baked. Neighbors dropped by unannounced, bearing pies and stories, their faces weathered but kind. It was a world away from the glittering excess of Gatsby’s mansion, where champagne flowed endlessly and strangers embraced like old friends.  

Yet, even then, I couldn’t shake the feeling that I was caught between two worlds. The East had changed me—its sophistication, its cynicism, its relentless pursuit of something just out of reach. I had seen the way people like Tom and Daisy moved through life, careless and cruel, leaving wreckage in their wake. And then there was Gatsby, with his impossible dreams, reaching for a past that never truly existed.  

Coming home was like stepping into a photograph, a moment frozen in time. But photographs fade, and so did the illusion of permanence. Each year, the West seemed a little smaller, the people a little more distant, as if they sensed I no longer belonged. My father would ask about my studies, my mother would fret over my thinness, and my sister would beg for stories of the East—stories I edited carefully, omitting the hollow glamour and the quiet despair.  

Still, for those brief weeks, I could pretend. I could walk the snowy streets and feel the old familiarity, the sense of being known. But the train always waited, and with it, the pull of the East—its promises and its betrayals. By the time I boarded again, the magic of Christmas had faded, replaced by the uneasy knowledge that home was no longer a place, but a memory.  

And so I would watch the landscape blur past, the West receding behind me, until all that remained was the echo of laughter and the ghost of pine in the air.

events.title: Ending Affairs: Jordan and Tom
detailed_summary: Before leaving, Nick feels compelled to resolve his situation with Jordan Baker.
He meets her and discusses their relationship and its aftermath.
Jordan listens impassively, dressed for golf.
She informs Nick she is engaged to another man, which Nick doubts but accepts.
As Nick gets up to leave, Jordan confronts him, accusing him of being the one who ended things ('threw me over').
She recalls their earlier conversation about bad drivers, implying Nick was another 'bad driver' she encountered and suggesting his proclaimed honesty was a facade.
Nick responds defensively, citing his age (thirty) as being past self-deception.
Feeling angry, regretful, and still somewhat attracted to her, Nick turns away.
Later, Nick encounters Tom Buchanan on Fifth Avenue.
Tom confronts Nick about seeming unwilling to shake his hand.
Nick asks Tom directly what he told George Wilson on the afternoon of the murder.
Tom confesses he told Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car.
He justifies this by claiming Wilson was armed, threatening, and forced his way into the house.
Tom asserts Gatsby deserved it for running over Myrtle without stopping.
Nick recognizes he can't argue with Tom's distorted version of events.
Tom laments his own 'suffering', mentioning crying over a box of dog biscuits found in the flat he shared with Myrtle.
Nick concludes that Tom and Daisy are careless people who destroy things and retreat into their wealth, letting others clean up their messes.
He shakes Tom's hand, feeling as if dealing with a child, before Tom enters a jewelry store.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then he went into the jewellery store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever.

events.text_segment:
There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. But I wanted to leave things in order and not just trust that obliging and indifferent sea to sweep my refuse away. I saw Jordan Baker and talked over and around what had happened to us together, and what had happened afterward to me, and she lay perfectly still, listening, in a big chair.
She was dressed to play golf, and I remember thinking she looked like a good illustration, her chin raised a little jauntily, her hair the colour of an autumn leaf, her face the same brown tint as the fingerless glove on her knee. When I had finished she told me without comment that she was engaged to another man. I doubted that, though there were several she could have married at a nod of her head, but I pretended to be surprised. For just a minute I wondered if I wasn’t making a mistake, then I thought it all over again quickly and got up to say goodbye.
“Nevertheless you did throw me over,” said Jordan suddenly. “You threw me over on the telephone. I don’t give a damn about you now, but it was a new experience for me, and I felt a little dizzy for a while.”
We shook hands.
“Oh, and do you remember”—she added—“a conversation we had once about driving a car?”
“Why—not exactly.”
“You said a bad driver was only safe until she met another bad driver? Well, I met another bad driver, didn’t I? I mean it was careless of me to make such a wrong guess. I thought you were rather an honest, straightforward person. I thought it was your secret pride.”
“I’m thirty,” I said. “I’m five years too old to lie to myself and call it honour.”
She didn’t answer. Angry, and half in love with her, and tremendously sorry, I turned away.
One afternoon late in October I saw Tom Buchanan. He was walking ahead of me along Fifth Avenue in his alert, aggressive way, his hands out a little from his body as if to fight off interference, his head moving sharply here and there, adapting itself to his restless eyes. Just as I slowed up to avoid overtaking him he stopped and began frowning into the windows of a jewellery store. Suddenly he saw me and walked back, holding out his hand.
“What’s the matter, Nick? Do you object to shaking hands with me?”
“Yes. You know what I think of you.”
“You’re crazy, Nick,” he said quickly. “Crazy as hell. I don’t know what’s the matter with you.”
“Tom,” I inquired, “what did you say to Wilson that afternoon?”
He stared at me without a word, and I knew I had guessed right about those missing hours. I started to turn away, but he took a step after me and grabbed my arm.
“I told him the truth,” he said. “He came to the door while we were getting ready to leave, and when I sent down word that we weren’t in he tried to force his way upstairs. He was crazy enough to kill me if I hadn’t told him who owned the car. His hand was on a revolver in his pocket every minute he was in the house—” He broke off defiantly. “What if I did tell him? That fellow had it coming to him. He threw dust into your eyes just like he did in Daisy’s, but he was a tough one. He ran over Myrtle like you’d run over a dog and never even stopped his car.”
There was nothing I could say, except the one unutterable fact that it wasn’t true.
“And if you think I didn’t have my share of suffering—look here, when I went to give up that flat and saw that damn box of dog biscuits sitting there on the sideboard, I sat down and cried like a baby. By God it was awful—”
I couldn’t forgive him or like him, but I saw that what he had done was, to him, entirely justified. It was all very careless and confused. They were careless people, Tom and Daisy—they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made…
I shook hands with him; it seemed silly not to, for I felt suddenly as though I were talking to a child. Then he went into the jewellery store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever.

Here is the full text segment from *The Great Gatsby* corresponding to the provided metadata:

---

There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. But I wanted to leave things in order and not just trust that obliging and indifferent sea to sweep my refuse away. I saw Jordan Baker and talked over and around what had happened to us together, and what had happened afterward to me, and she lay perfectly still, listening, in a big chair. She was dressed to play golf, and I remember thinking she looked like a good illustration, her chin raised a little jauntily, her hair the color of an autumn leaf, her face the same brown tint as the fingerless glove on her knee. When I had finished she told me without comment that she was engaged to another man. I doubted that though there were several she could have married at a nod of her head but I pretended to be surprised. For just a minute I wondered if I wasn’t making a mistake, then I thought it all over again quickly and got up to say goodbye.

“Nevertheless you did throw me over,” said Jordan suddenly. “You threw me over on the telephone. I don’t give a damn about you now, but it was a new experience for me, and I felt a little dizzy for a while.”

We shook hands.

“Oh, and do you remember—” she added, “—a conversation we had once about driving a car?”

“Why—not exactly.”

“You said a bad driver was only safe until she met another bad driver? Well, I met another bad driver, didn’t I? I mean it was careless of me to make such a wrong guess. I thought you were rather an honest, straightforward person. I thought it was your secret pride.”

“I’m thirty,” I said. “I’m five years too old to lie to myself and call it honor.”

She didn’t answer. Angry, and half in love with her, and tremendously sorry, I turned away.

One afternoon late in October I saw Tom Buchanan. He was walking ahead of me along Fifth Avenue in his alert, aggressive way, his hands out a little from his body as if to fight off interference, his head moving sharply here and there, adapting itself to his restless eyes. Just as I slowed up to avoid overtaking him he stopped and began frowning into the windows of a jewelry store. Suddenly he saw me and walked back, holding out his hand.

“What’s the matter, Nick? Do you object to shaking hands with me?”

“Yes. You know what I think of you.”

“You’re crazy, Nick,” he said quickly. “Crazy as hell. I don’t know what’s the matter with you.”

“Tom,” I inquired, “what did you say to Wilson that afternoon?”

He stared at me without a word, and I knew I had guessed right about those missing hours. I started to turn away, but he took a step after me and grabbed my arm.

“I told him the truth,” he said. “He came to the door while we were getting ready to leave, and when I sent down word that we weren’t in he tried to force his way upstairs. He was crazy enough to kill me if I hadn’t told him who owned the car. His hand was on a revolver in his pocket every minute he was in the house—” He broke off defiantly. “What if I did tell him? That fellow had it coming to him. He threw dust into your eyes just like he did in Daisy’s, but he was a tough one. He ran over Myrtle like you’d run over a dog and never even stopped his car.”

There was nothing I could say, except the one unutterable fact that it wasn’t true.

“And if you think I didn’t have my share of suffering—look here, when I went to give up that flat and saw that damn box of dog biscuits sitting there on the sideboard, I sat down and cried like a baby. By God it was awful—”

I couldn’t forgive him or like him, but I saw that what he had done was, to him, entirely justified. It was all very careless and confused. They were careless people, Tom and Daisy—they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made. . . .

I shook hands with him; it seemed silly not to, for I felt suddenly as though I were talking to a child. Then he went into the jewelry store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever.

--- 

This passage captures Nick's final interactions with Jordan and Tom, as well as his reflections on their careless natures.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. But I had come too far to turn back now, and the weight of it pressed upon me like the humid air of that relentless summer. 

It was Gatsby’s funeral. 

No one else seemed willing to take responsibility for it. The Buchanans had vanished—Tom and Daisy slipping away like shadows at dawn, leaving no forwarding address, no word of regret. Wolfsheim, that grotesque figure of the underworld, had sent a curt telegram expressing his regrets but citing business obligations that prevented his attendance. Even the partygoers, the countless faces that had laughed and drunk and danced in Gatsby’s halls, had melted into the anonymity of the city, as though they had never known him at all. 

And so it fell to me—Nick Carraway, the one who had watched it all unfold, who had stood at the edges of Gatsby’s world and seen the truth of it—to arrange the final farewell. 

The morning of the funeral was oppressively still. The sky hung low and gray, as though even the heavens were reluctant to acknowledge the passing of a man who had built his life on dreams. I stood outside the small, nondescript chapel, waiting for the handful of mourners I had managed to notify. The minister, a tired-looking man with a voice like dry paper, fidgeted with his Bible, casting occasional glances at his watch. 

Then, to my surprise, a lone figure approached. It was Owl-Eyes, the bespectacled man I had met in Gatsby’s library on that chaotic night of the first party I attended. He was slightly out of breath, as if he had hurried to get there. 

“I had to come,” he said, adjusting his glasses. “I couldn’t let him go entirely alone.” 

I nodded, grateful for even this small gesture. But as the minutes ticked by, it became clear that no one else would come. The man who had filled his house with laughter and music would be buried with only two witnesses to mark his passing. 

The service was brief, perfunctory. The minister’s words echoed hollowly in the nearly empty room. When it was over, Owl-Eyes lingered for a moment, shaking his head. 

“The poor son of a bitch,” he muttered, more to himself than to me. Then, with a final glance at the coffin, he turned and walked away. 

I stayed behind, staring at the casket that held all that remained of Jay Gatsby—the dreamer, the fraud, the man who had loved Daisy Buchanan with a devotion that bordered on madness. In the end, his wealth, his parties, his carefully constructed persona had meant nothing. He had died as he had lived—chasing a green light across the water, reaching for something just out of grasp. 

As I stepped out into the pale sunlight, I thought of Gatsby’s father, Mr. Gatz, who had arrived too late to see his son buried. He had shown me the worn copy of *Hopalong Cassidy* in which young Jimmy Gatz had scribbled his self-improvement schedule, that earnest blueprint for greatness. The old man had been proud, in his way, unable to see the tragedy of his son’s life—only the success he had imagined. 

And then there was Daisy. I wondered if she ever thought of him now, if she ever paused in her glittering, careless life to remember the man who had loved her so completely. But no—Daisy was not one for looking back. She and Tom were alike in that, retreating into their money, their vast carelessness, leaving the wreckage behind them. 

I took one last look at the cemetery, the rows of silent stones stretching into the distance. Somewhere among them lay Gatsby, alone in death as he had been in life, for all his crowds and noise. 

The wind picked up, rustling the leaves of the trees overhead. It sounded like whispering, like the faint, far-off echoes of laughter from one of his parties. But there was no laughter left now, only the quiet, indifferent hum of the world moving on. 

I turned away, knowing that I, too, would soon leave this place behind. The East had held me for a time with its glitter and promise, but now it seemed as hollow as Gatsby’s mansion, as empty as his grave. 

There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired, I thought. And in the end, we all slip back into the past, leaving nothing but stories behind. 

Gatsby’s story was over. Mine, for what it was worth, still had a few pages left. 

I walked to the waiting train, and did not look back.

events.title: Final Departure and Meditation on the Past
detailed_summary: Upon leaving, Nick notes Gatsby's house remains empty, the lawn overgrown.
He observes a local taxi driver who often points out the house, speculating the driver might have witnessed the accident and created his own narrative.
Nick avoids the driver, not wanting to hear speculative stories.
He recalls spending Saturday nights in New York, haunted by the vivid memories and sounds of Gatsby's parties.
One night, he sees a car arrive at Gatsby's house but doesn't investigate, assuming it's a late guest unaware the party is over.
On his last night, Nick visits Gatsby's house one final time.
He finds an obscene word scrawled on the steps and erases it with his shoe.
He walks down to the beach and lies on the sand, observing the closed shore houses and the Sound.
As the moon rises, the landscape seems to dissolve, leading Nick to contemplate the 'old island' as seen by the first Dutch sailors – a 'fresh, green breast of the new world'.
He reflects on the vanished trees that made way for Gatsby's house, symbols of the lost American dream.
Nick thinks of Gatsby's initial wonder at Daisy's green light, how close his dream seemed.
He concludes Gatsby didn't realize the dream was already behind him, lost in the vastness of America.
Gatsby's unwavering belief in the 'orgastic future' is highlighted – a future that constantly recedes.
Despite the elusiveness of the dream, Nick acknowledges the persistent human impulse to strive towards it ('run faster, stretch out our arms farther').
The chapter, and the book, ends with the image of humanity struggling against the current of time, constantly being pulled back into the past.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Gatsby’s house was still empty when I left—the grass on his lawn had grown as long as mine.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.

events.text_segment:
Gatsby’s house was still empty when I left—the grass on his lawn had grown as long as mine. One of the taxi drivers in the village never took a fare past the entrance gate without stopping for a minute and pointing inside; perhaps it was he who drove Daisy and Gatsby over to East Egg the night of the accident, and perhaps he had made a story about it all his own. I didn’t want to hear it and I avoided him when I got off the train.
I spent my Saturday nights in New York because those gleaming, dazzling parties of his were with me so vividly that I could still hear the music and the laughter, faint and incessant, from his garden, and the cars going up and down his drive. One night I did hear a material car there, and saw its lights stop at his front steps. But I didn’t investigate. Probably it was some final guest who had been away at the ends of the earth and didn’t know that the party was over.
On the last night, with my trunk packed and my car sold to the grocer, I went over and looked at that huge incoherent failure of a house once more. On the white steps an obscene word, scrawled by some boy with a piece of brick, stood out clearly in the moonlight, and I erased it, drawing my shoe raspingly along the stone. Then I wandered down to the beach and sprawled out on the sand.
Most of the big shore places were closed now and there were hardly any lights except the shadowy, moving glow of a ferryboat across the Sound. And as the moon rose higher the inessential houses began to melt away until gradually I became aware of the old island here that flowered once for Dutch sailors’ eyes—a fresh, green breast of the new world. Its vanished trees, the trees that had made way for Gatsby’s house, had once pandered in whispers to the last and greatest of all human dreams; for a transitory enchanted moment man must have held his breath in the presence of this continent, compelled into an aesthetic contemplation he neither understood nor desired, face to face for the last time in history with something commensurate to his capacity for wonder.
And as I sat there brooding on the old, unknown world, I thought of Gatsby’s wonder when he first picked out the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock. He had come a long way to this blue lawn, and his dream must have seemed so close that he could hardly fail to grasp it. He did not know that it was already behind him, somewhere back in that vast obscurity beyond the city, where the dark fields of the republic rolled on under the night.
Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that’s no matter—tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms further… And one fine morning—
So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Gatsby’s house was still empty when I left—the grass on his lawn had grown as long as mine. The once-vibrant mansion, which had thrummed with laughter and music, now stood silent, its windows dark and unseeing. The hedges, once meticulously trimmed, had grown wild, their branches twisting like the fingers of some forgotten ghost. Even the marble steps, where so many had stumbled drunkenly in the golden haze of summer nights, were cracked and stained with neglect.  

I paused at the end of the driveway, looking back one last time. The place had been a temple of dreams, a monument to a man who had built his life on the fragile foundation of hope. Now, it was just another decaying relic of the past, no different from the ruins of empires that crumble beneath the weight of time.  

The wind carried the faint scent of salt from the Sound, and for a moment, I imagined I could hear the echoes of Gatsby’s parties—the clink of glasses, the swell of jazz, Daisy’s laughter ringing like a silver bell. But the illusion shattered as quickly as it had come. There was no music now, no laughter, no golden girl in a white dress drifting through the rooms. There was only the whisper of the grass and the hollow sigh of the wind through the empty halls.  

I wondered what had become of the guests who had once filled those rooms with their careless revelry. Had any of them spared a thought for Gatsby after his death? Or had they simply moved on to the next party, the next distraction, as though he had never existed? The world, it seemed, had no patience for dreamers—especially those whose dreams were built on illusions.  

As I turned away, I thought of Gatsby standing on his dock, reaching out toward the green light across the water. He had believed in that light with every fiber of his being, had staked his life on the promise it held. But in the end, it had been nothing more than a mirage, a trick of the distance and the darkness.  

The road back to the village stretched before me, empty and quiet. The summer was over, and with it, the feverish energy that had gripped West Egg. The season of excess had passed, leaving behind only the brittle husks of what might have been.  

I walked on, the weight of the past settling over me like dust. Gatsby’s house faded into the distance, just another shadow on the shore. And though I knew I would never return, I also knew that the memory of it—of him—would linger, like the ghost of a dream that refuses to fade with the dawn.  

For Gatsby, the dream had ended. But for the rest of us, life went on, indifferent and unrelenting, as it always does.
